story: Paul McMullan’s rebirth as a Dundee United player is set to be confirmed with a new contract for next season.As recently as last August, the former Celtic kid was told he was free to find a new club.At that time Partick Thistle were showing a strong interest but he decided to stay on and fight for his place at Tannadice.And since Robbie Neilson took over as manager in October, the -year-old has made  appearances and is again seen as a part of the squad.McMullan was signed up by Ray McKinnon in the summer of  and was a regular until falling out of favour under Csaba Laszlo early this season.Under the current boss, however, he’s played his part in United hauling themselves back into the Championship promotion race.

title: dundee womens festival gears up for incredible schedule of 70 events
story: Women across the city and the world are being celebrated for their achievements at this year’s Dundee Women’s Festival.The theme of Hear Women’s Voices hopes to highlight the ied way in which women use their voice – be it through stories and language, arts and crafts, travel and expeditions, science, in the workplace or by exercising their right to vote.Nearly  events will be held at ious locations across the city over two weeks.These will range from special talks about women in history and science workshops held by those currently working in STEM , to art exhibitions and hands-on cookery, pottery and line dancing classes.The festival launched today with a centenary suffrage conference, aimed at  to -year-olds and encouraging them to vote by exploring the history of women’s suffrage and our current political system.A seminar held by Scottish journalist and broadcaster Lesley Riddoch – who interviewed women born in the s about their experiences in employment and care roles – will take place this evening at the Steps Theatre.Tomorrow two dferent films will be screened – the first an Italian silent film, with a live band accompaniment, about a laundress torn between men.In the evening a documentary will be shown about a young lawyer’s journey to joining the bench as the first female judge in the Islamic law courts, in the Middle East.There will also be a bag- making workshop, yoga classes and gym sessions, art exhibitions, swimming sessions, mindfulness workshops, Middle Eastern and Indian cooking classes, dance sessions and a chance to chat with surface pattern designer Kirsty Stevens of Charcot.Festival chairwoman Prue Watson said: “This is the international year of language which inspired our theme of women’s voices.“We wanted to hear women’s voices in whichever way they use them, whether that is though spoken language, telling stories, art or film – their skills are their voice.“It was only last year that for the first time a woman got an Oscar for directing a film, despite the fact women have been making films for many years.“And it took a long time for women to be accepted as artists, which is why we have included so many exhibitions.”Other highlights of the festival include an evening of story- telling with Radio  comedian Helen Keen, who will welcome a iety of speakers, and a short film about the history of Women’s Aid in Scotland told through the memories of those involved.Soap-making classes, ceramic workshops, Say No to Drama self-help workshop, creative digital classes, tours of HMS Unicorn and backstage tours of the Caird Hall will also take place.Prue added: “We always try to make the festival, which runs until March , as ied as possible to encourage a wide range of women of dferent ages and backgrounds to get involved in running events and attending them.”Organisers received funding from Rosa Women to Women Grant, Dundee City Council, and the Scottish Parliament.Many of the events are free but booking is essential as spaces are limited.For a detailed programme see dundeewomensfestival.org.uk.

title: leisure and culture dundee staff could be affected by redundancies
story: Employees at Leisure and Culture Dundee could be offered voluntary redundancy as part of drastic measures to reduce spending, it has been revealed.The exact extent of the cuts is unclear at present. The arm’s- organisation, which runs many of the city’s most popular attractions, says it needs to analyse a range of “savings and investment” options before taking any decision.Voluntary redundancies and early retirement schemes are on the table after Dundee City Council agreed £. million of savings at its annual budget meeting last month.The SNP administration said it would increase the management fee by £, compared to the previous year, but LC Dundee had a contingency fund of £, to cover pay rises which would allow it to make savings of £,.Other possibilities include increasing prices and memberships of its centres.LC Dundee is responsible for venues such as the Caird Hall, The McManus museum and the Olympia swimming pool. It also operates resources such as public libraries, which have been repeatedly threatened with reduced opening hours.The body recently hosted the Dundee Sports Awards at the Caird Hall which recognise successful sports clubs and iniduals.An LC Dundee spokesman confirmed its finance committee met this week to try to thrash out a plan, adding: “Management now intend to discuss recommendations made with staff in the first instance.“At the HR and equalities meeting scheduled for March , consideration will be given to a voluntary redundancy voluntary early retirement scheme which mirrors the policy decisions taken by Dundee City Council.”Dundee Labour group leader Kevin Keenan said: “I am surprised that LC Dundee board are planning or have to make cuts, given the briefing the Labour group received.“I hope the administration have not starved them of funding whereby the board propose closures of the size and scale the managing director warned the budget meeting about.”Council leader John Alexander said: “Every council in the entire UK is dealing with the negative consequences of the Tories’ fixation on austerity.“Unfortunately, that also means that the partners that the council works with are facing similar challenges.”

title: museum seeks people to have their memories of arbroath harbour recorded
story: Stories of the sea are being sought from people with a connection to Arbroath harbour.The Signal Tower Museum is inviting folk who lived by, worked at or visited the harbour to drop in for an informal chat and have their memories recorded at a drop-in event tomorrow, between am-pm, as part of a maritime heritage project.Museum officer Kirsten Couper said: “We wish to record the stories, traditions and memories of Arbroath’s unique fishing heritage. Were you a skipper, harbour worker, boat-builder, fish merchant or smokie-maker, or knew someone who was ”

title: politicians say its the right time for historic dundee clock to be replaced
story: Plans to replace the famous Lochee clock have been put in place by city councillors.The High Street clock was removed during regeneration works and found to be faulty.Parts for the old timepiece could not readily be sourced.SNP councillors Alan Ross and Roisin Smith said they contacted the council city development department, which has confirmed proposals will be coming forward in “due course”.Ms Smith said: “This is welcome news for Lochee.“It is particularly pleasing to see this come forward through community consultation, and the final design was chosen by the local community through a public display.“The previous clock was part of the fabric of Lochee and I am excited to see the replacement.”The project is to be funded through the community regeneration fund which granted £, for the project just before Christmas last year.

title: three dundee unions to meet about strike action after change to dundee council workers terms
story: Union members will meet on Monday to decide whether to take industrial action over changes to council workers’ terms and conditions.Two joint trade union meetings involving Unison, Unite and the GMB will be held at the Wellgate’s Steps Theatre to start the ballot process after unions were informed no further consultation would take place relating to changing council employees’ terms.It comes after union members protested against plans to change the voluntary redundancy policy.Under the changes, compulsory redundancies will be considered as a last resort and a two-year cap will be added to the flexible retirement scheme.Jim McFarlane, of Unison, said: “We want to hold a consultative ballot on whether to take industrial action.. We’ll also be running branch AGMs next week as this is the first time the council has changed workers’ terms and conditions without negotiations. We’re also looking to get an update on the budget situation next week.“It doesn’t feel right people working alongside each other could be working to dferent terms and conditions.“We have common interests to defend members against this decision. If we have no choice, industrial action could be taken.”A Dundee City Council spokesman said the council was still talking with trade unions.He said: “This policy#brings together how the council will handle change for employees in a clear and transparent way.“It follows a Cosla agreement with the local government trades unions in April , which committed councils to do everything they reasonably can to manage workforce change with sensitivity and compassion. The breadth of measures the new policy ensures are considered first – from redeployment and reskilling to early retirement and voluntary redundancy – underlines the council’s commitment to avoiding compulsory redundancies wherever possible and to promoting additional job options and prospects for any staff displaced by change in the way we provide services in the future.“The policy and resources committee also agreed changes to the flexible retirement scheme and salary conservation. Employees already on these schemes will not be affected. All of this was subject to discussion with the trades unions before a report was taken to committee.”

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: Demolition team pull down old college site
story: The work is being carried out by Bonnybridge-based Central Demolition and is set to finish in July.Cha Tulloch, from Central Demolition, said the project was on track after the initial internal sweep.ldquoThe first stage was soft stripping when we emptied internal furnishings which were left behind, like desks and chairs, and donated them to local charities and businesses, she said.The building, which dates back to the s, has been vacant since the new campus opened in . The .-acre site sits next to the cityrsquos new purpose-built justice centre, which is going up rapidly.Highland Council has earmarked the college site for mixed-use development.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness College students showcase work of Highland Hospice
story: DRAMA students at Inverness College UHI have teamed up with Highland Hospice to offer insight into the patient experience of palliative care.Third year BAdrama and performance students performed Homeward Bound, a -minute play charting one couplersquos experience of end-of-le care, after being approached by the hospice.Officials at the hospice were keen to see live drama used as an educational tool to help improve the quality of palliative care and the experience of those involved.The play was performed to staff and nursing and care students at the college, with hospice representatives providing commentary to provide context and insight into the experience.It proved such a useful educational tool, the drama students have been asked to perform the play again at the NHS Highland Highland Hospice Essentials in Palliative Care Conference at Eden Court in Inverness, on March -, where it will be filmed to be used in learning.Lesley Mickel, programme leader for the drama course, said: ldquoWe were delighted to work with Highland Hospice to develop this special performance, which really highlights the human impact of late diagnosis and the importance of quality palliative care.ldquoIt was not only a challenge for our students in terms of portraying these very raw, human emotions, it also proved an extremely useful educational tool for students studying other parts of the university curriculum, with our nursing and care students gaining a much greater understanding of the issues involved.Hospice learning and development practice lead Siobhan Neylon said: ldquoIt was such an honour to work with these wonderful students on this poignant and emotive drama.ldquoThey portrayed the characters in such a dignied way.Homeward Bound was written by playwright Brian Daniels and tells the true story of Lesley and her husband Seth Goodburn, who was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer at the age of . He died just  days after diagnosis.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness pupils donate money to city cycling charity
story: PUPILS at an Inverness secondary school have selected a charity which provides cycle outings for the elderly to receive pound in funding from the Young Philanthropy Initiative .The scheme is sponsored by the Aberdeen-based Wood Foundation and students in each school were asked to make presentations to fellow students and a  of judges who selected the winning team which had a chosen charity.Millburn Academy have donated their money to Cycling Without Age, Inverness ndash a charity with specially adapted bikes which takes residents from care homes and Highland Hospice on rides around the town and local countryside.Alice Munro, principal teacher of English, said the competition was a great experience for the pupils.ldquoThey invited people from ious charities to the school and went out to see the work these charities do in the local community. After their research, teams were asked to give a presentation and the judges were former staff members, the school chaplain and a police representative.ldquoThe winning charity, Cycling Without Age, is a fantastic organisation doing great work with the elderly in the community.Cycling Without Age spokesman Mick Heath said: ldquoIt began as an idea in the head of Dr Katie Walter of Cairn Medical Practice.ldquoShe recruited me to be her helper. It all began with a chance encounter in July .ldquoWe started networking and soon had a grant from HiTrans Active Travel to buy our first electric trike for taking the elderly and frail out for rides.ldquoWe were quickly joined by Dr Moira Finlayson and we three have been going at it flat out since then.The charity now has four trikes and several volunteer pilots and has taken more than  passengers on more than  rides.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: Shock at extent of tree felling by the Caledonian Canal in Inverness
story: Councillor Duncan Macpherson believes too many trees have been chopped down to make way for the latest phase of the Inverness West Link.Oak trees have been brought down along the canal side to make way for a second swing bridge and poplar trees along the edge of the A at Glenurquhart Road have also been felled in the name of health and safety.Cllr Macpherson said he and many others were shocked to see the extent of the felling.He said: ldquoI can understand the need to have one or two trees down for the new swing bridge but it seems to me like theyrsquove just gone and taken every single tree down. Did they really need to do that ldquoI wouldnrsquot exactly call myself a tree-hugger but Irsquom thinking lsquoguys come on, are you sure you needed to take that many down rsquoInverness musician Roderick Mackenzie, who lives nearby and is concerned about protecting the environment, said it made him feel ill to see mature trees being cut down.ldquoThis is abuse of the environment, he said. ldquoItrsquos sickening.A council spokesman said it was ldquoalways troubling to see mature trees removed but insisted the scale of the operation was necessary.And he said an environmental survey had been carried out before the felling started to rule out the presence of bird nests, bat roosts and similar habitats in the trees.He added: ldquoThe poplar trees adjacent to the A were in very poor condition and would have needed signicant reductions or complete removal, regardless of the development.ldquoPart of the stage two works will develop park land and there is a comprehensive replanting plan incorporated into the works commencing later this year.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: Ski slope plan for ex quarry outside Inverness
story: Inverness Snowsports Centrehas been told by Highland Council that it does not require an environmental impact assessmentat this stage for the proposed development at Torvean on the A Loch Ness road.ISC was formed by a group of snowsports and mountain bike enthusiasts who believe Inverness should have a venue for such activities for all ages and abilities.Project manager Helen Morgan said they envisage all-year-round attractions including mountain biking, zip wires, high rope trails and downhill tubing, all based around a snowsports core. It is estimated a pound million to pound million investment is required.The plan includes a building for catering, changing and hire of equipment, plusrooms available for rent.Panoramic viewing areas will be provided from where the sporting activities can be observed in comfort.The council has been told there will be ldquonegligible noise or light pollution as most of the development would be below the top rim of the quarry. There will be some removal of scrub trees and gorse and brambles, but mature trees will not be felled.The area is a Site of Special Scientic Interest as it is formed by an esker, an unusual geological feature where a long ridge of gravel and other sediment has been deposited by meltwater from a retreating glacier or ice sheet. It is one of the reasons gravel extraction was halted back in the s.The area is now used by dog walkers, ramblers, motorbike scramblers and X off-road fans.Inverness Snowsports Centre has launched an online Just Giving plea to raise pound, to pay for the studies required to support a formal planning application.Keen skier Miss Morgansaid they wanted to ensure people of all abilities had access to the activities.Cllr Bill Boyd, Inverness West, said: ldquoThis plan sounds quite exciting, but I hope they can come up with funding because the council is not in a position to fund it at the moment.ldquoIt could be an ideal centre for local people, schools and visitors.Sunday  Mar  : AM

title: joes lewis the squad is hungry to win games and win trophies for aberdeen
story: Joe Lewis says his desire to win a trophy with Aberdeen is stronger than ever, having suffered cup-final heartache.The Dons take on Rangers tomorrow at Pittodrie in the quarter-final of the Scottish Cup.The Reds are trying to win the tournament for the first time since  after some near misses in recent years.Derek McInnes’ men have been defeated semi-finalists in  and  and, in , an injury-time winner from Celtic’s Tom Rogic beat them in the final.Goalie Lewis joined the club in  and the Englishman was between the sticks for the final two years ago.As well as the pain of that loss the keeper has also experienced defeat by Celtic with Aberdeen in League Cup finals in and this season .Lewis is desperate to join the elite group of Dons players that have delivered silverware for the club and hopes they can defeat Rangers tomorrow as they aim for Scottish Cup glory.The -year-old said: “The expectation when you come to Aberdeen is to win trophies.“I’ve been to one Scottish Cup final in my first season and you want to get to another final and win it this time.“That has got to be Aberdeen’s aim in every cup competition to try to win it.“We need to be ready to deal with what comes our way on Sunday and try to progress.“The final is the last game of the season andyou’re involved in that you want to finish on a high.“We need to get there first, but everyone in the dressing room wants to be part of a team that wins a trophy here.“There is only Shay Logan, Andy Considine, Niall McGinn and Mark Reynolds who were here when the club last won a trophy.“It would be greatthis group of players could have that as well.“Everyone in the squad is hungry to win games and win trophies for Aberdeen.“I would love to win more than one trophy, but I haven’t managed to win one yet.“But one of the reasons you come to play for Aberdeen is to win trophies.“We have an opportunity to do that in the Scottish Cup, but right now Rangers are in our way on Sunday and we need to try to get through.“You don’t really look at the big picture until the end of the season.“During the season you’re just focusing on each game as it comes.“Maybe at the end of a season you reflect on your time with a club andyou haven’t won trophies you may think that’s something you would like to have had. But right now I want to make sure we do win a trophy.”The expectation of the Red Army for the Dons to win trophies is something Lewis relishes.He came to Pittodrie after spells with Blackpool, Fulham, Cardf and Peterborough, where it was extremely dficult to win silverware.Lewis added: “In England there are very few teams that can win a trophy due to the finance at the top.“The top three or four teams are very dficult to stop and you see Manchester City, who are on for the quadruple, and I wouldn’t put it past them to get it.“Away from the top teams, the vast majority don’t have much chance.“I came up here as an Aberdeen player to win trophies and the club have a great history of doing that.“It hasn’t happened for a long time, but since the gaffer has come to the club that expectation has ed.”In four meetings with Rangers this season Aberdeen have won twoand drawn onebut they lost the most recent clash - at Pittodrie last month.Ahead of the latest meeting with the Gers, Lewis believes they can take confidence from the brace of victories against Steven Gerrard’s side this term.He said: “I think we can take confidence from those results and I think we can take confidence from the last performance against them.“Things didn’t go our way and the result didn’t go our way that night.“But I think there were a lot of positive aspects from that game.“In a cup game a result is all that matters so we need to make sure we have ruthlessness defensively in our -yard box and also ruthlessness in attack to take chances in their -yard box.“Hopefullywe do that then we’ll get through the tie.”

title: aberdeen charity charlie house launches new partnership with teca
story: An Aberdeen children#s charity has announced a two-year partnership with a major new concert venue.Charlie House, which supports children and young people with complex disabilities and le- limiting conditions, has secured a deal with state-of-the-art The Event Complex Aberdeen .A vital link for the city charity, it will also see the exhibition centre create a dedicated changing place for families with children with complex disabilities.TECA, which will replace the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre , is on track to open in summer this year at its new location in Bucksburn.Susan Crighton, director of fundraising at Charlie House, said: “We are thrilled to announce this key partnership for   and very much look forward to working with the team. story: School pupils are to showcase their talents with two upcoming concerts.Children attending secondary schools in Aberdeen are coming together for the spring concerts at the Beach Ballroom.Taking place at .pm next Friday and Saturday, Friday’s show will feature the Aberdeen City Council music ensemble’s training band, youth band and guitar ensemble.Saturday’s event will include the training strings group, youth orchestra and choir.Councillor John Wheeler, education operational delivery convener, said: “The spring concerts are a marvellous  for our young musicians to display their talents.“The music service does a wonderful job of nurturing these talents and already this year we have reaped the rewards.”Tickets can be purchased online from Aberdeen Performing Arts.

title: residents welcome plans for 500 home development on outskirts of aberdeen
story: Residents have voiced their views on plans to build more than  new homes in their community.Cognito Oak LLP has applied to Aberdeen City Council to build the new residential development at Cloverhill, Bridge of Don, on land east of the A Ellon Road.The proposals will include at least % affordable housing, to contribute towards the demand for homes at a local and national level.Proposed community facilities include parks, inclusive play areas, a recycling centre, community meeting space, shops and cafes.Residents had the chance to offer feedback at a public consultation yesterday at St Columba’s Church. vw, px"  Willie Mitchell, , has lived in the area for the past  years and has welcomed the proposed development.He said: “I’m really impressed by this. Right now there are just a lot of potholes.”A new signalised junction with pedestrian crossings and a reduced speed limit is also planned to improve connectivity and enhance road safety.A -year-old woman, who asked not to be named, has lived in the area for  years. title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. title: islay adds character to new whisky film
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowA new film will tell the tale of Scotland#s national drink # the legendary water of le.Scotch: The Golden Dram, a revealing feature documentary on how whisky became the spirit of choice around the globe, is set for UK release on March .The film, by Parkland Entertainment and Munro Films, will have its European premiere at the Glasgow Film Festival on March .Shot on location among the stunning Scottish countryside, Scotch: The Golden Dram tells the story of uisge-beatha, Gaelic for #water of le#, which is enjoyed in more than  countries, generating more than  billion in exports each year.The film charts the Cinderella tale of legendary master distiller Jim McEwan, a veteran with more than  years standing in the industry, who takes on the dilapidated Bruichladdich distillery on his home island of Islay and turns it into an award-winning blend.Some of the other ardent enthusiasts featured include Richard Paterson, a master blender whose nose was insured for . million, as well as biochemist whisky-maker Dr Bill Lumsden, and master distiller Ian MacMillan.The film marks director-producer Andrew Peat’s feature- documentary debut, a passion project for the American filmmaker who studied at St Andrew’s University.Andrew Peat said: #The heart of our film is the characters, the men and women who produce Scotch whisky, from the barley farmers to the bottle makers. And you can literally see the passion and joy and pride they have in their work and this world-renowned product.#They share their amazing stories, and some very humorous anecdotes. It#s a very educational film , but at the same time it#s a film of the heart.#You will laugh and possibly cry by the time the credits roll.#David Adams McGilp, VisitScotland regional director, said: #Boasting an incredible number of distilleries, Islay is a Mecca for whisky-lovers across the world. It’s great to see the island feature so heavily in the documentary Scotland: The Golden Dram with four distilleries included.#As well as its whisky offering, Islay provides stunning scenery, a wide iety of wildle and a warm Scottish welcome. I hope this film will encourage visitors to travel here to enjoy the water of le, and the island’s remarkable tourism offering.#View a trailer for Scotch: The Golden Dram.

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: familys new hope 85000 raised
story: NewsFamilys new hope as £, is raised to send son to America for cerebral palsy treatmentThe six-year-old will be heading to America after the huge sum of money was raised to fund his treatment.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  MAR NewsSaul with brothers Clay and Mylo and mum and dad, Karen and Stuart "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family’s bid to help their son walk again is set for take-off. Little Saul Wylie will travel to America for le-changing treatment on his severe form of cerebral palsy. The six-year-old, who weighed just lb at birth, has made the waiting list for pioneering surgery. There has been a massive charity effort across Ayrshire to fund the trip, with pound, raised in little over six months.Mum Karen, , told the Ayrshire Post : “To achieve this so quickly is beyond our wildest dreams.“We set a target of two years to get the money but the community reaction has been incredible.” Saul, of Tarbolton, has to go to the States because his aggressive condition is not treated on the NHS. The brave kid lives with spastic diplegia cerebral palsy, which affects his muscle tone and leaves him unable to walk unaided. Karen said: “Saul’s dream is to be able to stand by himself and take independent steps and maybe even one day walk around school with his friends. “Like every parent, we long for endless opportunities for our boy. “Saul is very happy and determined but we just want him to have the best opportunity at a better quality of le and to become as independent as possible.”  Medication, Botox, and even trampoline therapy have all been used to try and limit Saul’s pain. But his spot at St Louis Children’s Hospital in Missouri could be the ultimate answer. Karen said: “The operation is called selective dorsal rhizotomy, which will reduce Saul’s muscle stfness. “Added to intensive rehab, it will allow Saul to stand independently and potentially walk again. Unfortunately there is a waiting list for international patients so Saul’s surgery is not scheduled until . “But because we are in a position to go we have been put on their cancellation list and are keeping our fingers crossed.” Karen and husband Stuart have thrown themselves into a string of fundraising events with the ‘Steps For Saul’ campaign gathering momentum. Karen said: “We’ve done everything from coffee mornings to quiz nights and we can’t thank people enough for their response. “There have been skyes, race nights, sponsored cycles and I also did the Great Scottish Run. “People have taken Saul to their hearts and we’ve even had donations from as far afield as America, New Zealand, Canada and Ireland. “Hopefully he now has the chance he deserves.” • An open ice skate for Saul will take place at Ayr Ice Rink on Sunday, April , from -pm.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnDrugsCerebral palsyCharityAyr NewsAyr

story: NewsPlans to re-open former bank as a High Street market face more delaysThe project, originally scheduled to open in September , will not open its doors until May at the earliest.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsThe building remains idle on Ayr High Street "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA landmark project to redevelop a High Street eyesore has been delayed again. South Ayrshire Council’s attempts to open a pound million market have been hit by more inactivity. Bosses claim they are now targeting a May opening date – almost two years later than scheduled. Officials this week admitted they had suffered “signicant delays” in their bid to reopen the former Clydesdale Bank and Suburbia Bar. An initial revival date of September  was promised when council chiefs began their transformation of the site. Last February former Ayr Renaissance boss David Bell said: David Bell said: “Work is scheduled to be complete in late spring this year, when we’ll open the ground floor as a market square to help create a busy new attraction for Ayr town centre.” But the finished article has never materialised. The ill-fated Renaissance team bought the building in March  with a view to breathing new le into the bottom end of the town. The site is where farmers sold their corn to merchants from the s to . And the vision for a new market was formulated to hark back to Ayr’s glorious status as county town. A council spokesman admitted: “There have been signicant delays to this project. However, we are committed to opening the market and events space as quickly as possible for the people of Ayr and beyond. “We have a short specialist fit-out contract to complete, which should be ready for the start of May so that the building can be used for markets and events from the summer.” Ayr councillor Martin Dowey said: “It has been one sorry excuse after another with this building and frankly the people of Ayr and beyond deserve far better.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnClydesdale BankSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyr

story: NewsSleazy OAP, , who took pics of Ayr schoolgirls in mini-skirts told youre guilty all day longRetired architect Ross McKay was told by a sherf he "should be able to control" himself at his age.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsRoss Mackay was placed on the sex offenders register "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner who took pictures of schoolgirls in mini skirts will be on the sex offenders’ register for the next three years, writes Edwin Lawrence. Sleazy retired architect Ross McKay will also be kept under court supervision for the same period. McKay, , insisted he was innocent of the sordid behaviour but he was found guilty after a trial last month. Sherf John Montgomery told McKay: “You have been convicted of conduct which, in my estimation, contains a substantial sexual element and a signicant sexual aspect by clandestinely taking photos of female schoolgirls wearing short skirts. “At  years of age you really should be able to control yourself more appropriately than you have done by indulging in this sort of behaviour.” Sherf Montgomery warned McKay: “I detect an air of defiance from you, both at your trial and in what you have told the author of your criminal justice social work report. “My advice to you is keep a low profile. Do not put yourself in a position where it can be construed you have the aim of self-gratication.” Defence lawyer Gillian McBlane successfully argued against the imposition of a stringent sex offender prevention order against her client. This was requested by depute fiscal Vicky McMillan, and would have kept McKay out of public parks and well away from schools.   Ms McBlane said: “He is first offender and there is little to suggest he presents a signicant risk to the public.” Sherf Montgomery reminded her: “He continues to deny responsiblility.” But Ms McBlane maintained: “He very much recognises the authority of the court and he has assured me of his commitment to any order you might impose.” McKay, of Ardlochan Terrace in Maidens, insisted at his trial that he had not taken the photos of Belmont Academy schoolgirls in mini skirts that were found on his phone. He also denied stopping his car in Peggieshill Road to take the images, although the court heard evidence of a vehicle with the same registration as McKay’s parked there. The offences took place in mid- and again in March . Sherf Montgomery told McKay at the trial: “There is overwhelming evidence it was you in your car. “You’re guilty all day long.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSex crimeAyr NewsAyr

title: tributes paid mr gaiety ayr
story: NewsTributes paid to Mr Gaiety as Ayr theatre legend Bernard Cotton diesBernard Cotton was a do-it-all theatre manager in the Gaietys pomp and booked acts like Billy Connolly, Ken Dodd and Barbara Windsor.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsBernard outside his beloved Gaiety "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe man who was ‘Mr Gaiety’ in Ayr for nearly two decades has died suddenly, aged , writes Edwin Lawrence. Bernard Cotton was at Alloway Bowling Club when he collapsed and died on Thursday last week. He had been club champion on ious occasions, the last time in . But it was as manager of the Gaiety from  to  that Bernard made his biggest impact. He took over at a critical time when the theatre’s ownership passed from the Popplewell family to the Royal Burgh of Ayr. But Bernard was the perfect man for the job, having managed the Empire Theatre in his home town of Sunderland. There he had hosted shows featuring The Beatles and Hollywood legend Marlene Dietrich. “He even shared a McEwan’s Export with Marlene,” said son Sam, . “They didn’t have any champagne to give Marlene so she had what dad was drinking - only with ice.”. Bernard was no ordinary theatre manager and often directed big showpiece events like pantos and summer season shows. He quickly became respected by some of the biggest names on the Scottish scene. He booked acts like Jimmy Logan, Billy Connolly, Rikki Fulton, Jack Milroy and perennial Gaiety favourite Johnnie Beattie. Bernard also knew some of the biggest UK stars, bringing Ken Dodd, Barbara Windsor, Pat Phoenix and Lionel Blair to the Gaiety.  He did not shy away from tough decisions, booking the controversial erotic revue ‘Oh! Calcutta!’ in . He later recalled: “It brought much adverse publicity and even the poster was frowned upon - to such an extent that the management agreed to cover over the female posterior that was displayed upon it.” However, the show was a massive financial success with only two unsold seats in a week-long run. Sam remembers his dad sharing a story of a couple walking out of the show in high dudgeon. Bernard asked them why, as it had been advertised as an X-rated show. The shocked couple told him they thought they had booked to see ‘Oklahoma!’. Another of Bernard’s controversial - but highly successful - bookings was ‘The Rocky Horror Show’, which attracts enthusiastic fans who often dress in stockings, corsets and suspenders. For although Bernard principally ran a family theatre, he believed it should cater for all tastes. A post on the Gaiety Facebook page says: “We are deeply saddened to hear about the loss of Bernard Cotton, a much loved colleague, dedicated family man and friend to all. “Bernard was and is a Gaiety institution, from his own time managing our Old Lady to helping us shape her future. We simply couldn’t have done it without his support. “His guidance, golden nuggets from years gone by, witty humour and love for delivering high-quality theatre for all were second to none. He will be sorely missed by us all. “At this sad time we are thinking of his beloved we Vida and children Julia and Sam. “We wish them moments of peace and comfort as they remember a husband, father and friend who was so cherished. “He will forever be in our hearts and minds and will always have a place in his beloved theatre.”  Musician Martin Henderson commented: “Bernard was witty, professional and a family man, a privilege to have worked for many years in the Gaiety while Bernard and Vida were at the helm. “He ran a tight ship but embraced risky ventures like our annual mock panto, which needs no explanation to Gaiety staff. A sad loss to Scottish theatre and his family.” Journalist Alistair Nicol said: “I met Bernard when I was deputy editor of the Ayrshire Post in  and he was always helpful and a great inspiration to all around him in the entertainment world.” Bernard Cotton was a former president of the Rotary Club of Ayr He is survived by we Vida, a stalwart Gaiety volunteer who formerly ran the theatre’s costume department London-based daughter Julia, , a former dancer and Brighton-based son Sam. His funeral service is at noon on Wednesday, March , at Masonhill Crematorium.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnBilly ConnollyFacebookThe BeatlesAyrSocial mediaAyr News

title: hare-raising-exhibition-arrives-in-the-borders
story: A SPECTACULAR celebration of colour, art and creativity is coming to the Borders Textile Towerhouse in Hawick.Northumbrian textile artist Helen Cowans brings her Bounding and Moon Gazing: Hares in Contemporary Textiles exhibition to the Borders for the first time.The exhibition, which features textile wall-art as well as hare-themed dresses, opens on Saturday, March .Helen told us: ldquoI love drawing with a needle and thread."I use traditional and contemporary embroidery ndash both hand and machine ndash combined with hand-dyed, weathered and painted fabrics."My recent work has been based on hares: I admire their form, movement and character.A qualied tutor and professional lecturer who has taught City  Guilds embroidery courses, Helen now works freelance in a studio in her garden amidst the wild, windswept hills of north Northumberland, where she creates textile works for the wall, as well as costumes and D sculptures.Helen added: ldquoIn a past le, I worked in a laboratory as a molecular biologist."I prefer stitching and reading history.Following the successful joint exhibition with Emma Jolly, Two Artists, at Hawick Museum, Helen is ing to the town with her solo exhibition.Bounding and Moon Gazing: Hares in Contemporary Textiles will be displayed in the Exhibition Room at Borders Textile Towerhouse.There will also be an opportunity to see Helen at work at the same venue on Sunday, June .Zilla Oddy from promoters Live Borders said: ldquoThis exhibition gives the public the chance to see textiles, craft and art combined in a skilful and imaginative way."We are delighted to bring the exhibition to Hawick, as encouraging creativity is one of Live Bordersrsquo aims as a charity.The exhibition, which is free, at the Borders Textile Towerhouse runs from Saturday, March  to Sunday, June

title: dean-and-yvonne-bring-vagabond-voices-to-selkirk
story: REGARDED as among Scotlands finest exponents of Americana, Vagabond Voices, are set to play Selkirk next month.Dean Owens and Yvonne Lyon will touch the soul and take the String Jam Club audience from Caledonia to the Southern states badlands and back with their own unique and entertaining blend of Americana, roots, rock and pop grooves.Irvine Welsh has described Dean Owens as Scotlandrsquos most engaging and haunting singer-songwriter.While BBC Radio Scotland presenter Iain Anderson believes listening to Yvonne is a le affirming experience. She is the bees-knees.Dean is a genre jumping artist, with roots in both his home town of Edinburgh and his spiritual home of Nashville.Echoes of both shine through his music ndash Celtic spirit, country soul.He has toured extensively in the UK and in  undertook his first US tour, including headlining at the legendary Levitt Shell stage in Memphis.His latest album release lsquoSouthern Windrsquo was included in numerous Best of  lists, including Ralph McLean , Another Country with Ricky Ross , and Country Music People .Described as ldquoone of Scotlandrsquos best by Whispering Bob Harris and winning four and five star reviews across the board, the title pinnacle won the prestigious lsquoUK Song of the Yearrsquo Award at the Americana Music Awards UK .Yvonne is a prolic title: pet-of-the-week
story: This weeks Pet Of The Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, is Shadow.The charity told us: "Shadow has been with us for over a year now through no fault of his own. Shadow is around five years old and is a German Shepherd Cross. He is looking for an experienced owner who can help him settle into his new home and give him some stability, the poor boy had a few homes before coming into our care, so his next home needs to be his forever home."Although he is really a gentle giant, Shadow is a very big and powerful dog, so anyone interested must seriously considerthey are physically able to manage him."Furthermore, being such a big dog, he will need a home where he has enough space inside and also a fully secure garden which is big enough for him to play in."Shadow is looking for a quiet home without young children or cats and, while he doesnt mind spending a bit time with some other dogs, he would really prefer a home where he would be the only dog. He can take a while to learn to trust new people but when he does, Shadow is your best friend and loves to give a paw!"If you would like to offer Shadow his forever home, please email info@borderspetrescue.org for more information and an application form."

story: A FORMER Borders MP has been appointed independent chairman of Borders Citizens Advice Consortium.Calum Kerr, who represented the Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk constituency for the SNP from  to , has described his new role as ldquoa real honour.ldquoAt a time when austerity continues to have a detrimental impact on many families and people in the Borders, itrsquos a privilege to be involved with an organisation that does vital work supporting those that need help in our communities.Prior to being elected, Mr Kerr served as a voluntary director of Citizens Advice Direct.Lucy Orsquo Leary, chairwoman of Central Borders Citizens Advice Bureau said: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted with Calumrsquos appointment.ldquoAs an MP, Calum was very supportive of our organisation and has an acute understanding of the many issues affecting people and families living in the Borders and we look forward to working with him.

title: dealer-admits-selling-ecstasy-to-12-year-olds-in-galashiels
story: A DRUG dealer from Hawick who sold ecstasy tablets to two -year-olds has been told he could have been facing a murder charge.The schoolboys fell ill after taking taking the pills which contained compounds of the class A drug and required urgent medical treatment.Despite being born with no arms, Jake Moffett overcame his disability by supplying the ecstasy tablets to the two youngsters and pleaded guilty to a drug dealing charge at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Sherf Peter Paterson told the -year-old: "If you dont know this by now, I will tell you this is an extremely serious mater."Supplying class A drugs is a serious matter but to children aged  makes it a lot more serious."It could easily have killed them and you could be facing a charge of murder."Calling for background reports to be prepared before sentencing, the sherf warned Moffett that he would be remanded in custodyhe did not co-operate in the preparation of the reports and failed to turn up for appointments.Tessa Bradley, prosecuting, explained that the police report indicated that Moffett was "very popular among local youngsters" with a major feature being large groups congregating for the consumption of alcohol.She said that Moffett met a -year-old boy in Victoria Park, Galashiels, at around .pm on Thursday, October , and sold him the tablet.The fiscal described how the boys mother went to bed that night leaving her son playing video games.She said: "She got out of bed later on to get some medicine and found her son with large pupils and visibly shaking."The schoolboy received medical treatment and later confirmed that he had purchased the ecstasy tablet from Moffett.A search warrant was obtained for Moffetts home in Crumhaugh Road, Hawick, where pound in cash was recovered along with pink tablets and a mobile phone.Ms Bradley also described an incident on October  when another -year-old had taken what he believed to be an ecstasy tablet and after being found by his mother had to receive treatment at Borders General Hospital.The boy confirmed he had bought the tablet from Moffett.Moffett pleaded guilty to being concerned in the supply of compounds of ecstasy at his Hawick home between August  and October .Sentence was deferred until March  for the production of a Criminal Justice Social Work Report and a Restriction of Liberty Order assessment.

title: platinum-plaudits-as-stobo-is-honoured-by-first-minister
story: A BORDERS health spa is leading the way in people power - by going platinum.Stobo Castle has become the first employer in Scotlands entire hotel sector to gain the Investors in People Platinum Award.And its such a big deal, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon turned up to make the presentation.For nearly  years Investors in People has been recognised internationally as a leading accreditation for workforce management.Stobo Castle now employs over  staff - and accounts director Yvonne Cowan couldnt hide her delight on Wednesday as she collected the platinum award.She told us: "As the only business in the Scottish hotel sector to achieve this prestigious award, we are extremely proud of, and grateful to, the team of hard-working management and staff at Stobo who contributed to our IIP success."Such is our enthusiasm to continue to improve how we manage and develop our people, we look forward to working towards the next challenge.The IIP Platinum accreditation is the highest accolade that can be achieved and is currently held by only one percent of all IIP accredited organisations.First Minister Sturgeon said: ldquoMy warm congratulations to everyone at Stobo Castle."Achieving this recognition is testament to the excellent work of the staff and management, and their commitment to the development of their workforce."An organisationrsquos employees are its most valuable asset, and I would encourage all businesses to work towards these extremely high standards.Stobo Castle has just celebrated  years of pampering and now welcomes around , guests each year.Bonnie Clarke from Investors in People in Scotland added: ldquoThis is a fantastic achievement for Stobo Castle, congratulations!"Investors in People recognises organisations who are truly committed to their people, continuous improvement and customer service."We have supported Stobo Castle since  and wersquore delighted to see their ongoing dedication recognised with this Platinum award."

story: A PENSIONER who admitted her third drink driving offence has been warned she could be sent to jailshe commits a similar crime.Seventy five year old Eileen Clark pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to driving while more than double the legal alcohol limit in her home village of Newstead.She admitted driving with a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes - the legal limit being  - on the night of Saturday, February  and has been banned from the road for three years.The court heard that the retired languages teacher, fromMain Street, Newstead,had been driving back from Melrose and had collided with a kerb causing a puncture to a tyre.Defence lawyer Greg McDonnel accepted it was his clients third drink driving conviction but said the offences had been committed over a -year period.However, he added that she will no longer be driving.Mr McDonnel said: "She realised she could be marginal but still took the chance to drive."Sherf Peter Paterson told Clark: "This is the third time. title: selkirk-and-valleys-prepare-for-walking-festivals-silver-anniversary
story: ITS already Scotlands longest-running walking festival.And later this year Selkirk, along with the Ettrick and Yarrow valleys, will stretch the Scottish Borders Walking Festival a few more miles.The  festival will run for an entire week from Saturday, September .Sue Briggs, who is a member of this yearrsquos organising team, told the Border : ldquoWe are delighted that Selkirk and the surrounding Ettrick and Yarrow valleys have been chosen to host the Scottish Borders Walking Festival in this special th year.ldquoWe believe this yearrsquos festival will have something for everyone, with walks led by Scottish Borders Councilrsquos Ranger service, volunteer walk guides and local people alongside special interest themed strolls and a full social event programme. story: A GALASHIELS-based project that supports young people into long-term employment has received a pound, cash boost, thanks to a regional housebuilder.Works+ was selected by Persimmon Homes East Scotlandrsquos as its latest Community Champions winner.The national match-funding scheme supports groups and charities which improve the quality of le or environment across the region.Working with unemployed between  and  from across the Borders, Works+ delivers a -week course that helps them into employment.Scott Wight from Works+, who made the application, said: ldquoWe are thrilled to receive this funding from Persimmon Homes East Scotland."The young people that we work with benefit greatly from the structure of our course."Our main aim is to improve their self-confidence and reignite their passion and drive that is often lost during their time at school or a symptom of being unemployed."A total of  percent of our participants secure education, training or employment opportunities within the  weeks and a recent visit to Persimmon Homes prompted our application for funding to help us to continue to support young people across the Borders.Each person taking part in the programme receives ongoing support for a period of  months through a tailored aftercare plan to ensure that the new role is sustained.Iain Innes, managing director at Persimmon Homes East Scotland, told us: ldquoWe are very proud to help, Works + ndash the programme that they offer is vital to helping young unemployed people into long-term work.ldquoIt is extremely important to us that we support the communities that we are working and we will continue to support Works Plus in any way that we can.The Persimmon Homes scheme invites local groups and charities to bid for cash from a national fund, with two donations of up to pound, being made locally each month.Organisations can apply for funding by completing a simple online form at www.persimmonhomes charity

title: selkirks-dagenham-drama-is-a-delight
story: THERES a red flag flying over the Victoria Hall this week.And dont be too surprised to see a burning bra or two hanging from the flagpole as well.Politics, profanities and a perfectly-sized piece of social history are being served up this week by the talented cast and crew of Selkirk Musical Theatre Company.Be warned though, Made in Dagenham is a steer away from the normal Victoria Hall productions.Peppered with sexual innuendo and shop-floor fs, its not exactly a family-friendly night at the opera.But it is a damn good show - and a foot-tapping reminder of the swinging sexism of the late s.For anyone who enjoys those wonderful kitchen-sink dramas of the decade - A Taste of Honey, Saturday Night and Sunday Morning, or Poor Cow - this is for you.Although, in fairness, at times it feels more Sid James than Shelagh Delaney as the humour and slapstick of Carry On provide plenty of laughs.And for anyone, like myself, who doesnt already know Made in Dagenham the Musical, dont despair... the songs, like the early Ford Cortinas, are instantly adorable.Kirsty Cleland has all the allure of a young Rita Tushingham as she enchants, enthrals and entertains in the lead role.As a strike-leader and long-suffering we, the Galashiels actress is both convincing and commanding.And the ever-reliable Stuart Mitchell, who plays hard-done-by husband Eddie, has to be at the top of his game not to be outshone.But, in true socialist fashion, Made in Dagenham the Musical isnt just about the leads... everyone has their part to play - and how well they play it.Tracy Borthwick is having a blast as the potty-mouthed Beryl.And Amanda Blacklock is pitch perfect as the hapless Clare who attempts to keep up with the flow of double-entendres.Ellen McFadzen, with her Viv Nicholson hair-style and shortening mini-skirts, is a delight as sassy Sandra.And the shopfloor resolve is perfectly pitched by Ellen Halliday, as Cassie, and Julie Craig, as Connie.Relationships, friendships and even governments are tested in this factual story which, historically, helped females eventually earn an equal footing when it came to filling up pay packets.Robin Murray could challenge Mike Yarwood with his hilarious performance as Harold Wilson.And hes regularly brought down a peg or two by the feisty Rachel Inglis as Barbara Castle.Made in Dagenham the Musical is a battle of the classes as much as the sexes, with Jodie Millar and Yvonne Mitchell providing some gentried grace.The dialogue is a delight, the foot-to-the-floor pace is perfect, and the choreography, costumes, straight from Carnaby Street, and score makes sure this is a production that will strike a chord for decades to come.But for any musical production to be a success, it needs songs.From the brilliant opening scene, this show doesnt disappoint.Busy Women, Everybody Out and Viva Eastbourne are nothing other than tremendous encore numbers that bring out the very best of this talented cast.But perhaps the highlights are Julie Craigs sensational take on the riveting Same Old Story, Rachel Inglis reaching the high notes in the incredible Ideal World, and the delightful duet of Stuart Mitchell and Kirsty Cleland with the making-up masterpiece Im Sorry, I Love You.Made in Dagenham the Musical is a celebration of women fighting for their rights.While it succeeds, this move away from the comfort zone is more of a testament to just how good Selkirk Musical Theatre Company has become.If you havent yet got your tickets... join the picket line quickly and dont be disappointed.Made in Dagenham the
