on her Brexit plans by March .The PM said thather deal is rejected, MPs will be able to vote on whether the UK can leave the EU in a no-deal scenario, andthat is rejected, the Commons can decide on whether to extend Article  and delay Brexit.Meanwhile, EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said he does not believethe UK will have enough time to approve Mrs Mayrsquos withdrawal deal by the scheduled exit date of March .Mr Barnier suggested a ldquotechnical extension of up to two months may be needed.Askedhe thought it was possible to reach an agreement by March , evenWestminster gave the green light this month, Mr Barnier told Spainrsquos El Mundo newspaper: ldquoNo.Mr Barnier has also stated that Brusselsis ready to give the UK further ldquoguarantees, assurances and clarications that the Irish backstop should only be temporary.

title: qa-the-low-down-on-harry-and-meghans-baby
story: ndash When is the royal baby due A six-months-pregnant Meghan told well-wishers on a day trip to Birkenhead in January that her due date was the end of April or the beginning of May.ndash Is it a girl or a boy Meghan has insisted they do not know whether they are having a girl or a boy and that it will be a surprise.ndash Where will the baby fall in the line of succession Seventh in line. The baby will bump Harryrsquos uncle, the Duke of York, into eighth place in the line of succession.Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie move into ninth and th place, and the Earl of Wessex ndash the Queenrsquos youngest son ndash drops out of the top  for the first time to th in line.ndash How will the baby be related to the Queen The baby will be a great-grandchild of the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh, and the Prince of Walesrsquos grandchild, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridgersquos niece or nephew, and a cousin for Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis.ndash Will he or she ever be monarch Unlikely. Future king George, plus Charlotte and Louis, are all further up the line of succession than Harry and Meghanrsquos baby, so it is a safe bet that the throne will stay on the Cambridge side of the family in years to come.The Prince of Wales with his family in the garden of Clarence House.The photo was taken by @ChrisJack_Getty to mark The Princersquos th birthday. pic LmnUYnDmdash Clarence HouseNovember , ndash What will the baby be called Latest odds at the bookmakers have Diana as the favourite for a girl, followed by Alice, Victoria and Elizabeth.For a boy, Arthur, James, Philip, Edward and Albert are among the predicted choices.William and Kate chose royal favourites for their children.But Harry and LA-born Meghan could break the royal mould and take inspiration from American traditions.In the US, the most popular name for a baby girl is Emma and Liam for a baby boy.ndash Will the baby be a prince or princess Not at this stage. They will not be a prince or princess, nor an HRH, because George V limited titles within the royal family in .ndash So what will their title be A son would be known as the Earl of Dumbarton ndash because a first son of a duke is allowed to use one of his fatherrsquos other lesser titles as a courtesy title.Harry was also made Earl of Dumbarton on the morning of his wedding, as well as being given a dukedom.A daughter would be LadyMountbatten-Windsor.ndash But the Queen could change this Yes. The Queen stepped in ahead of Georgersquos birth to issue aLetters Patent to ensure all the Cambridgesrsquo children would have fitting titles, but this royal baby is much further down the line of succession.Under George Vrsquos rules, Harry and Meghanrsquos child and any future children would eventually become princes or princesses when Charles becomes king, because they would be the children of a son of a sovereign.So even though the baby will be quite far down the line of succession, the Queen may decide to introduce the titles early so they do not have to be changed later on ndash unless Harry and Meghan prefer to adopt more low-key titles for their children.ndash Will Harry and Meghan hire a nanny There have been rumours that Meghan will turn to her mother, Doria Ragland, for help initially.But it is likely they will hire a nanny eventually.Harry has been close to all his nannies, especially Tiggy Legge-Bourke, and it is expected he and Meghan will arrange for a nanny to care for their baby while they are on official engagements.Kate and William have the help of their full-time live-in nanny, Maria Teresa Turrion Borrallo.Meghanrsquos close friend, Jessica Mulroney, had two nannies to help her with her twin boys and younger daughter.ndash Where will the baby be born Kate had three successful deliveries at the private Lindo Wing at St Maryrsquos Hospital in London so Meghan could follow her sister-in lawrsquos tried and tested lead.Harry was also born there in , as was William in .But with the Sussexes moving to Frogmore Cottage in Windsor Great Park, Meghan may want to have her baby closer to home.The duchess might even decide to have her baby at home ndash as was once always the custom for royal babies ndashwith a team of top medical staff on hand and the latest birthing equipment on standby.Other options include the Mulberry Birth Centre at Frimley Park Hospital in Camberley, Surrey, which is  miles from Frogmore Cottage.It does not offer private care for maternity patients, but Meghan could still be attended to by Guy Thorpe-Beeston, surgeon-gynaecologist to the household, and Alan Farthing, the Queenrsquos surgeon-gynaecologist, who cared for Kate during her deliveries,she chose.It was the hospital that saved the le of the Countess of Wessex following complications during the birth of her daughter, Lady Louise Mountbatten-Windsor.Sophiersquos son, Viscount Severn, was also born there in .Will the baby have dual citizenship Harry and Meghan could apply for their child to have dual US-UK citizenship.Meghan is planning to become a British citizen ndash but at present is still a US citizen.According to the American Embassy in the UK, a child born outside the US and in wedlock to a US citizen parent and a non-US citizen parent may acquire US citizenship at birththe US parent lived in America for five years ndash two of which were after the age of .

title: glasgow-school-one-of-the-last-private-girls-secondaries-in-scotland-to-close
story: Craigholme School, on the South Side, will shut its doors in August after being unable to resolve financial dficulties.Last year, the school joined forces with Kelvinside Academy, in the West End, in a bid to survive, but under a formal merger the school will now close in August.All pupils will be transferred to Kelvinside to complete their secondary education, although the fate of staff is more uncertain.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesTeachers may face redundancies unless new positions can be found at Kelvinside.The primary school at Craigholme, which accepts both boys and girls, will remain open as a feeder school for Kelvinside.The closure comes at a dficult time for private schools with steadily falling pupil rolls across the sector following the financial crash of .Since then fees have risen by more than  per cent, with the average annual cost to families climbing from some pound, to its current figure of around pound,. Fees at Craigholme topped pound, a year.The closure also marks another blow for single sex education in Scotland. There are now only four private girlsrsquo secondary schools left and one in the state sector.Craigholme hit the headlines in  when it emerged former pupil Aqsa Mahmood had dropped out of university to join Islamic State in Syria, where she was believed to have married an ISIS fighter.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesDonald Wilson, chair of the board of governors at Kelvinside Academy and Craigholme School, said the closure of the senior school would now follow the merger.Mr Wilson confirmed pupil numbers at Craigholme had dropped signicantly in recent years, while the impending impact of the Barclay Review, which will see removal of business rates relief, and other financial pressures, presented signicant challenges to all independent schools in Scotland.It has not yet been decided whether the facilities and land owned by the school will be sold off or retained for use by Kelvinside.Craigholme was founded in  by Jessie Murdoch as Pollokshields Ladiesrsquo School. title: who-are-scotlands-funniest-60-people
story: Lubna KerrWho the heck is Lubna Kerr  Pharmacist or comedian Pakistani or Scot Weegie or Edinburgher  Kerr is all those things, and her current show is a hilarious exploration of the hot political topic of identity. Where is she really from  Ask heryou dare. Just dont expect a straight answer ...Lubna Kerr, Where Are You Really From , Yesbar, March  Christopher Macarthur-BoydFor the past few years the buzz on the Scottish stand-up scene has been that Macarthur-Boyd is the future ndash androgynous, boyish, at home with getting laughs out of themes of mental health, masculinity and loneliness. The -year-old boy-man hails from the East End of Glasgow and jokes that he lives up to its tough image. ldquoYou wouldnrsquot want to bump into me in a dark alley ndash because yoursquod feel guilty about leaving me there. Watch this space.Christopher Macarthur-Boyd, Home Sweet Home, The Stand, March  Work In Progress, The State Bar, March  Richard GaddIn  Richard Gadd won the Edinburgh Comedy Award for his painfully honest and revealing show Monkey See, Monkey Do, about toxic masculinity and his own experience of sexual assault. A reminder that comedy can go to the darkest places. Jay LaffertyA regular on Radio  and Radio Scotland, Jay Lafferty has been on the stand-up circuit since  and has performed everywhere from Tokyo to New York. She brings her  Edinburgh Fringe show Wheesht! to the Glasgow Comedy Festival later this month.Jay Lafferty: Wheesht! is on at Blackfriars Basement on Friday, March . John Gordon SinclairThese days hersquos writing crime books, but for some of us he will always be the lanky, maladroit schoolboy from Bill Forsythrsquos Gregoryrsquos Girl. Sinclair was the cinematic equivalent of a Postcard single, a walking rejection of all those old tired west of Scotland macho male stereotypes. Bella Bella. Julia SutherlandJulia Sutherland is a stand-up because she was forced to be. A former on-air sidekick to Fred MacAulay on his radio show, she was entered in a stand-up competition as a stunt for the show and ended up having to do five minutes of material. People laughed. She thought: I can do this and she has built a career on it ever since. You might have also heard her interviews with comedians on Radio .Julia Sutherland, New Material Night, Yesbar, March    and Exposed, The Stand, March  Lex McLeanMcLeans nickname was Sexy Lexy which was of course ironic, given the comic had a comfortable face on top of which to place his checked bunnet. But the last of the great music hall comedians always had the last laugh with great Pavilion Theatre gags such as "To whoever stole my anti-depressants ndash I hope youre happy now." The Bodgers Absolutely: Jack Docherty, Gordon Kennedy, Moray Hunter and Peter BaikieThe quartet formed The Bodgers as school friends in Edinburgh and from this emerged Absolutely, the Channel Four comedy that bucked the trend by being a hit on TV then radio. Bred characters like rabbits, but most memorable have to be the stout men and women of Stoneybridge Town Council. If only Stoneybridge had been in charge of BrexithellipJack Docherty: Miekelson and McGlashan ndash Serious Men, Kings Theatre, March  Lynn FergusonFabulous Ferguson, from Cumbernauld, is an award winning writer, performer and stand-up. Now based in the US, running a storytelling coaching business, her first play was Heart and Sole, about a woman who falls in love with a fish. She joined the judging  for the International Emmys and hosted their Comedy Panel in New York. Her brother is comedian and talk show host Craig Ferguson. Arnold BrownIf stand-ups comedians were compiling this list, then therersquos every chance that Arnold Brown would be in the top ten such is his status among people who try to make other people laugh. Why did the Glaswegian not become a bigger star  Perhaps itrsquos because his slow style seemed too slow for television, but Brown was always best on a small stage: he built his reputation in smoky rooms and then, after the smoking ban, in non-smoky rooms and thatrsquos where hersquos continued to this day. If you donrsquot like alternative comedy, then Arnold Brown is one of the men you should blame. Rhona CameronRazor-sharp Cameron, from Dundee, is a stand up comic and writer who shot to fame in  after winning Channel rsquos So You Think Yoursquore Funny  She co-wrote and starred in Rhona, a sitcom about a lesbian Scot living alone in London, which was shown in . She played the first ever female narrator in The Rocky Horror Show. Susan CalmanFormerly a lawyer, Calman switched to stand-up in , and became a regular on  shows and comedy dramas like Fresh Meat. But it was her sparkling appearance on Strictly Come Dancing that made her a household name. Asked, once, when she was happiest, she said, ldquoGenuinely ndash and my we, Lee, knows this ndash dancing with Kevin Clton on Strictly. Calman has also written about her depression, in Cheer Up Love, and joy, in Sunny Side Up: A Story Of Kindness And Joy. Emma ThompsonCan we claim her  Scots mother. House north of the border. Of course, we can. Thompson is best known for her serious turns these days, but she cut her teeth in the Cambridge Footlights, did TV sketch shows Alfresco and Thompson, and then gave us Suzi Kettles in Tutti Frutti. Andwersquore taking Emma, can we take sister SophieThompson too  Jonathan WatsonHis career stretches back to Naked Video and Local Hero, and he is best known for his -year sht on Only An Excuse, but Watson has come into his tragicomic own in Two Doors Down, where he and Doon Mackichan have turned Cathy and Colin into the Liz Taylor and Richard Burton of Glesga. John ByrnePaisley-born Byrne is best known as a painter but anyone who has seen it knows therersquos wit in his work ndash a wit that becomes even more apparent when he swaps canvas for paper and brush for pen. His autobiographical series of plays, the Slab Boys trilogy, is a landmark of late th century Scottish theatre . Meanwhile his cult status as a writer of small screen fare was assured the moment the credits rolled on the first episode of Tutti Frutti, the BAFTA-laden  series which starred Robbie Coltrane, Emma Thompson and Richard Wilson. Iain StirlingldquoBasically, said voice of Love Island, Iain Stirling, as he launched the new BBC Scotland channel last week, ldquoIrsquom the only comedian in Scotland who has managed to make his voice more recognisable than his actual face. Stirlingrsquos crazed, pantomimic, querulous voiceover has been the best thing about Love Island. His voice and face are now wanted all over.. Hersquos even a go-to for advice on the Millennial condition, which he doles out in his book Not Ready To Adult Yet: A Totally Ill-informed Guide To Le. Karen DunbarDunbar was a national treasure in the making right from when she arrived, nostrils-flaring, on our televisions in Chewin The Fat, delivering us classics like Fiona the lonely shopkeeper. Since then shersquos done just about everything from panto and stand-up, to Calendar Girls: The Musical, and a TED talk about comedy. Plus, hers was the voice that delivered the Commonwealth Games to the world, saying, ldquoThis is our house and youre all very welcome. Harry LauderWhen Harry Lauder met Charlie Chaplin in  it was one huge world star meeting another. Itrsquos sometimes forgotten that: just how big a star of music hall and comedy Harry Lauder was. Like Chaplin, Lauder passed the biggest test of comedy and entertainment there ever was: a loud, drunken audience in a music hall. Hersquod also entertained his fellow miners when he worked down the pits and his great skill was the comic song touched with pathos. He knew how to make people laugh but he knew how to cry as well: his son was killed on the Western Front during the First World War. Ken BruceYes, him off the radio. The trained chartered accountant from Glasgow is not, it is fair to say, a well kent face on the stand-up circuit, but his gently humorous, easy-osey manner on Radio  every morning makes everything all right with the world for millions. Jonathan Ross is a big fan. Rab Christie and Iain ldquoNoddy DavidsonPick a hit comedy series over the past two decades ndash Rab C Nesbitt, Still Game, Burnistoun, Scot Squad, Gary: Tank Commander, Chewinrsquo The Fat, Limmyrsquos Show ndash and chances are their names are on the credits. Christie is managing director of The Comedy Unit and Davidson a producer director. Danny BhoyAs you read this Daniel Danni Chaudhry is about to begin a huge tour of Australia and New Zealand where he is, by all accounts, ldquohuge. You can understand why. Originally from Moffat, he is a likeable, adroit purveyor of observational comedy. James FinlaysonEmigrated to America in  and made a living in theatre before moving to Hollywood where he became the fth Beatle to Laurel and Hardy. No-one has ever done a double take head move better than the boy from Larbert. Una McLeanScottish acting royalty McLean, from Strathaven in South Lanarkshire, can turn her hand to comedy sketch shows, panto, serious theatre and film. She is currently appearing in BBC Scotland drama series River City. Her career began at the Byre Theatre in St Andrews in  and in , she starred in Scotlands first one-woman television show, Did You See Una  Chic MurrayThe Godfather of surrealist comedy  Probably. Murray also had a free range style that allowed for music hall gags "kippers ndash fish that like a lot of sleep" and the rather more philosophical. "Get into yourself to get yourself out of your self. Then try to lose yourself." They driest delivery this side of Gobi desert milk run also helped him sell surreal jokes such as "I drew a gun. He drew a gun. I drew another gun. Soon we were surrounded by lovely drawings of guns." Most modern comedians worship at the altar of Murrays memory. Sanjeev KohliFor years Kohli, who as a youngster worked in his familyrsquos convenience stores, was the comic king of the cornershop, delivering us laugh after belly-laugh from behind a counter, as Navid Harrid, the grey-bearded shop-owner in Still Game, or as Ramesh Manju in award-winning, cult radio comedy Fags, Mags  Bags. Now a regular on River City, hersquos left the shop behind, playing banker-turned-baker AJ, and recently appeared in the biopic Stan And Ollie. Ivor CutlerIt was George Melly who maybe summed up the late Ivor Cutler best: ldquoVery funny in a sinister sort of way. The Scottish poet, songwriter and humourist grew up in a Jewish family in Govan, appeared in The Beatles film Magical Mystery Tour and was a favourite of John Peelrsquos. Proof that England doesnrsquot have a monopoly on eccentricity. Jerry SadowitzFew comedians dare take their stand-up to the places Sadowitz has been known to go, probably for good reason. The humour is as black as the trademark top hat, the material wince-inducingly controversial and the live shows chaotic and aggressive, meaning TV appearances have been rare . Despite this, the Glaswegian remains one of the most influential ndash and isive ndash stand-ups of the last  years. Bruce MortonBruce Morton did the best comedy show ever. March  at the MacBob in Stirling when he was touring Blood Below the Window, his autobiographical one-man show, which was hilar , but had a sucker punch of hurt at the heart of it. Apart from his dalliance with Channel  , Morton has always been too marginal a figure for his talent. But no one is better at hearing the comic music of the Scots tongue. Dorothy PaulThe undisputed Queen of Scottish comedy, the Dennistoun woman is as funny as she is loved by Glaswegians who love to be taken down memory lane to a world of jeely pieces and fumbles and the dancin. Paul convinced as an excellent actress in the likes of The Steamie, and more recently Still Game, but it was her live touring shows that revealed her glorious skills of holding an audience in the palm of her hand. Robert Florence and Iain ConnellThe duo behind sketch show Burnistoun brought us characters such as Jolly Boy John, Biscuity Boyle and Quality Polis, as well as co-writing the sitcom Legit which starred Clare Grogan, Jordan Young and Raymond Mearns. Florence will front topical satire series, The State of It, on the new BBC Scotland channel.Iain Connell: Work In Progress, Blackfriars Basement, March  and  Robert Florence is Biscuity Boyle: My Bastart Le - One Last Time!, Oran Mor, March  and  Ronni AnconaOne of the best impressionists of her generation, Ancona, who grew up in Troon, is also an accomplished stand-up and an impressive actor. But itrsquos her uncanny ability to capture everyone from Nigella Lawson to Audrey Hepburn, Victoria Beckham to Ruby Wax, Renee Zellweger to Jenner Saunders that continues to amuse. Scotland The WhatThe talented triumvirate of Buff Hardie, Stephen Robertson and George Donald ruled the North-eastin the s, s and early s with the now-neglected art of comedy revue. Dont miss the phone call to the Queen, inviting her to open Oldmeldrums sports day . Fern BradyFern Brady reached the finals of So You Think Youre Funny at the  Edinburgh Fringe and hasnt looked back since. The performer from Bathgate is bold, honest and at times startling ndash listen to her trashing of heterosexual marriages, or her take on Australias abortion laws ndash but never less than very funny. Whats not to like about a former journalist and stripper whos dryer than the inside of a sand lizardrsquos top lip and more blunt than the new Mary Poppins. Janet BrownThe Rutherglen-born actor and impressionist will always be best-known for her memorable impersonation of Margaret Thatcher at the height of her pomp, which cropped up throughout the s and s everywhere from Mike Yarwoodrsquos popular Saturday night show to Bond film For Your Eyes Only. Gerard KellyKelly, from Glasgow, was a panto favourite in the city and a talented serious actor, but his big break was as hapless bank worker and would-be author Willie Melvin in the BBC Scotland comedy City Lights. He was the lynchpin of a stellar cast . He died in  following a brain aneurysm. Jane McCarryShe steals the show as loveable busybody Isa Drennan on Still Game. As the hit BBC Scotland comedy bows out later this month, who wouldnrsquot love to see Isa and shopkeeper Navidget their own spin-off series  The campaign starts here. Robbie ColtraneColtranemade his name in the alternative comedy movement of the s before becoming a household name. He was brilliant as a criminal psychologist in Cracker he appeared in two Bond movies he was an outsize presence as Hagrid in the Harry Potter films. In the  C series National Treasure he was outstanding as Paul Finchley, an ageing comedian suddenly beset with allegations of historical rape and sexual assault. Richard WilsonIf you ever see Richard Wilson in the street, do not shout his catchphrase at him. In fact, donrsquot even think about the catchphrase. Yoursquore thinking about it now arenrsquot you  The thing is, Wilson was, and is, much more than catchphrase comedy. He once said that there was some of his dad in Victor Meldrew, star of One Foot in the Grave, and some of the writer David Renwick too, but the point is that, as he shakes his fist at idiocy, there is some of all of us in him. Arabella WeirShe coined the catchphrase "Does my bum look big in this " for The Fast Show, lit up our screens as long-suffering neighbour Beth in Two Doors Down and most recently had a star turn on comedy drama Pure as a mother whose OCD-suffering daughter is plagued by sexually explicit thoughts. Janey Godley and Ashley StorrieFrom Godleyrsquos ldquoTrump is a c*** sign held aloft as the US president visited his Ayrshire golf resort in  to Storriersquos hilarious parodies of Harry Potter, Game of Thrones and The Handmaidrsquos Tale becoming viral hits, this mother and daughter are fearlessly chipping away at comedyrsquos glass ceiling. Godleyrsquos Nicola Sturgeon Theresa May Big Soup Pot skits are on the money.In Conversation with Janey Godley, City of Glasgow College, March  Janey Godley:  Years  Counting, Oran Mor,March - Ashley Storrie: Hysterical is at The Stand Comedy Club, March  and  Greg McHughThe Edinburgh born actor struck comedy gold when he dreamed up the character of Gary McLintoch, a soldier with a fictional Scottish regiment who delivers bon mots in broad Embra in much-loved mockumentary Gary: Tank Commander. McHugh also starred in Channel rsquos Fresh Meat, written by Peep Show creators Jesse Armstrong and Sam Bain. He has since moved on to straighter roles ndash hersquos currently in Channel  spy drama Traitors and Skyrsquos A Discovery Of Witches ndash but donrsquot think wersquove seen the last of Corporal McLintoch. Alan Cumming and Forbes MassonDrama school pals Cumming, from Aberfeldy, and Masson, from Falkirk, performed as musical double act and Kelvinside men Victor and Barry throughout the s and s, before finding success separately on stage and screen here and in the US. They briefly reunited in similar guise for the sarcastic, surreal cabin crew comedy The High Le alongside Siobhan Redmond. Stanley BaxterStanley Baxter once cleared the streets with his television specials that attracted m but the Glaswegian suffered all his le from anxiety and a need to be in control. As a result, Stanley, who lives in North London, offered up product sparingly, the world having the opportunity to see his Dietrich or his Coward only episodically. What he has created however is an incredible Bafta-winning legacy. LimmyIf you like your comedy surreal with a good dash of daft, Glaswegian Brian Limond has been the go-to purveyor for more than a decade. Arguably the first true UK comedian of the internet age, Limmy grew a loyal local online audience with his strangely loveable band of characters ndash who could forget former heroin addict Jacqueline McCafferty or frustrated adventure gameshow host Falconhoof  ndash but has found national recognition thanks to TV, live shows and two books.Limmy, Surprisingly Down to Earth, and Very Funny, Oran Mor, March , ,  and  Alastair SimYou have to be very serious to be good at comedy and Alastair Sim was very serious, particularly about his stage career. But itrsquos the films we love. Like A Christmas Carol. Is Simrsquos the greatest Scrooge  Probably. Or Laughter in Paradise in which hersquos a good man forced to go bad to inherit some moneyAnd The Belles of St Trinians of course in which he plays the headmistress Millicent Fritton. British comedy finds pretty much nothing funnier than a man in a dress but Alastair Sim did it best. Gregor Sharp and Simon CarlyleThe creators and writing partnership behind Two Doors Down which is hands-down one the funniest comedies to grace our TV screens in recent years with echoes of sitcom greats ndash from Abigails Party to The Royle Family ndash in its winning formula. More please. Gregor FisherThe ragtag Govan philosopher Rab C. Nesbitt was, as Fisher once noted, "somebody who was forgotten, somebody from the so-called underbelly of society." Indeed he was, but Nesbitt managed to be one of the funniest comedy characters to emerge from Scotland, and one of the most poignant, too. He made us laugh but the laughs were sometimes uncomfortable ndash there were lots of acute social truths in them. Daniel SlossNetflix-approved and still not , Sloss has the armour-plated arrogance of youth. Sometimes that can come across as simply arrogance. But, as his latest show X, which tackles toxic masculinity, proves, he is ambitious for his comedy. He also has the stagecraft. In other words, hersquos good now, but how good is he going to be  years from now  Michelle GomezFrom unhinged staff liaison officer Sue White in Green Wing to murderous Missy in Doctor Who, Gomez brilliantly nails weirdly offbeat, deeply funny characters. The Glaswegian, also known for comic turns in The Book Group and Bad Education is currently appearing in the Netflix supernatural horror series Chilling Adventures of Sabrina. The KrankiesThe Krankies in the top  best Scottish comedians of all time  Are we mad-dabi-dozi  Not really: remember that Janette and Ian Tough were masters of three neglected areas of comedy: the club circuit, which is where they first made their mark in the s comedy for children on Crackerjack and the likeand pantomime, which the Krankies have dominated in Scotland for years. And no, wersquore not defending the single they released. It was not fan-dabi-dozi. No-one danced all night. And it was not all right. Rory BremnerHeonce fooled Margaret Beckett, then a minister in a Labour cabinet minister, into thinking she was talking on the phone to the Chancellor Gordon Brown. She wasnt, of course: it was the mischievous Bremner, who had Browns distinctive burr down to a T. The spoof was a reminder of his formidable impersonation skills and his gt for political satire. The hit Channel  show, Bremner, Bird and Fortune, is much missed. Rikki FultonNotmany comedians can make us laugh merely by saying lsquohellorsquo. Watch, on YouTube, any of Rikki Fultonrsquos turns as Rev I.M. Jolly on the Hogmanay Scotch and Wry shows, and you see just that: the lights going up, and Rikki, with an almost audible sigh, uttering that ineffably melancholy lsquohellorsquo. Fulton had been one-half of Francie and Josie, had starred in iety and panto, and was a serious actor, too. The Rev I.M. Jolly became a Hogmanay must-see for many Scots. Ashley JensenJensenwas fetchingly eccentric as Ricky Gervaiss best friend, Maggie, in the Gervais Stephen Merchant-penned TV hit, Extras. She has gone on to refine her comedic and acting gts in TV and in film, including Ugly Betty and Agatha Raisin. The good news is that she can be seen alongside Gervais again in After Le, Rickys latest dark comedy, in which he plays a man struggling after the death of his we. It starts on Netflix on March . Ford Kiernan and Greg HemphillThe co-creators, writers and stars of Still Game and Chewinrsquo The Fat have more than earned their place among the upper echelons of Scottish comedyrsquos hall of fame, gting the nation an enduring lexicon that includes ldquoTwo pints, p**** ldquoThatrsquos plenty! ldquoYoursquove taken that too far and ldquoTake a drink!. Ronnie CorbettBoth venerated and under-ratedEdinburgh-born Corbett came for the fore during the satire boom of the s. But it was in the s and s that his star truly ascended, courtesy of his double act with Ronnie Barker and the programme they fronted, The Two Ronnies. Notionally he was the straight guy, but only notionally as subsequent generations of comics knew full well: David Walliams, Matt Lucas, Stephen Merchant and Ricky Gervais were among those who sought him out in his later years. Frankie BoyleDark and pessimistic humour. Close to the bone jokes. Brutal analogies. Boyle stokes controversy with his no-holds-barred subject matter. A rare family-newspaper-friendly sample: ldquoLas Vegas and Glasgow have a lot in common: theyrsquore the only two places in the world where you can pay for sex with chips. Kevin BridgesImpish, irreverent, clever, the natural successor to Connolly on the comedy stage ndashhe has the desire to keep going. Bridges manages to take seemingly ordinary le experience and turn it into something far less than ordinary. And he clearly has a head for political satire. "Working in Poundstretcher for no wageshellipworking in a shop where everything is worth a quid except you. Elaine C SmithA bona fide national treasure, Elaine C Smithrsquos career to date has encompassed not just comedy but also singing, straight acting , journalism, political campaigning, even teaching, all delivered with the aplomb and brio of a natural raconteur who excels at everything she turns her hand to.Typically, however, she has a more self-effacing take on the motives behind her genre-defying years in the spotlight. The idea, she once said, is to ldquojust keep moving ndash yoursquoll be less of a target. Seriously, though, nobody is likely to be taking aim at the star, who turned  last year: the charisma oozing from her when shersquos in character is unforced, and off-stage shersquos as warm, personable, generous and defiantly un-starry as you would expecther to be.Smithrsquos list of achievements and associations runs the gamut from Ato, wellnot Z than at least as far as W, standing for Wildcat Theatre. Smith first encountered its politically-inspired progenitor, :, at the Citizens Theatre in Glasgow as an -year-old and, suitably inspired, performed regularly with Wildcat throughout the s, including in the original production of The Steamie. Among her other credits in serious acting roles are BBC One drama Two Thousand Acres Of Sky and Kay Mellorrsquos hit series The Syndicate.But itrsquos for her contribution to comedy that shersquos best known and in particular for the role filed under M: Mary Nesbitt, aka Mary Doll, aka the long-suffering spouse to Govan nersquoer-do-well Rab C Nesbitt, he of string vest and filthy gutties fame.Smith clocked up her first of many Rab C episodes when the show debuted with a one-off pilot episode in late , and she was still there in  for the New Yearrsquos Day Special which found Rab fighting the bedroom tax. As an integral part of the much loved and award-winning show, shersquos now firmly embedded in Scotlandrsquos cultural DNA.Nobody will ever hail Mary as a role model for Scottish women or a worthwhile advert for hands-off parenting, but as an iconic comic character therersquos no touching her, and itrsquos hard to see who  in the Scottish acting firmament could have done her justice.Away from the dysal world of the Nesbitt family Smithrsquos comic skills have been put to good use in pantomimeand in less nihilistic TV sitcoms such as City Lights, in which she starred alongside the great Gerard Kelly, and in current hit Two Doors Down .Importantly, Smith also developed her own one-woman show, first mounting it in the mid-s and blazing an inspiring trail for a generation of younger Scottish actresses and comics to follow. And follow they have, another reason Elaine C Smith sits so high on our Scotlandrsquos Funniest People list.An Audience with Elaine C Smith, Kings Theatre, March  Armando IannucciIn an era when fake news is both a reality and a slur to be flung at reputable media organisations by emotionally incontinent politicians, it often feels ascurrent affairs and the reporting off them have moved way beyond satire. Which may explain why Glasgow-born writer, producer, director and arch-satirist Armando Iannucci is heading into space for his next project ndash Avenue , a sci-fi comedy for HBO starring Hugh Laurie.Butthe next chapter in the Scotrsquos comic journey takes place off-planet he leaves behind a treasure trove of earth-bound gems and itrsquos on account of that three decade back catalogue that he ranks so highly in our Scotlandrsquos Funniest People list.Cerebral and opinionated, with a liking for the scabrous and possessed of the outsiderrsquos eye which is vital for satire, Iannucci cut his teeth at BBC Radio Scotland in the late s on the likes of Norsquo The Archie McPherson Show. But those same gnashers first left their mark on the wider cultural landscape when he co-created Steve Cooganrsquos Alan Partridge character for BBC Radio rsquos On The Hour in . In  Iannucci and On The Hour co-star Chris Morris took the show to television as news parody The Day Today but Coogan and Iannucci would continue the Partridge association across three more series following the inimitable Alan, surely one of British comedyrsquos greatest creations, from the highs of television stardom to the lows of a static caravan and a berth on Radio Norfolk.In , Channel  gave Iannucci his own self-titled show. Inexplicably, it ran for only one season but had it not then we may have missed out on the show that came next ndash The Thick Of It, a fly-on-the-wall style mockumentary which debuted in  and burrowed its way into the heart of the New Labour machine where it dispensed satirical headbutts to one and all. Many, though not all, of these were delivered by another inspired Iannucci creation, spin doctor and full-time sociopath Malcolm Tucker. He was played in the show by Peter Capaldi, another Glaswegian of Italian descent whose family were actually near-neighbours of the Iannuccis in Springburn.Of course with so much of the UKrsquos political and media landscape being influenced and affected by the United States, the endlessly ambitious Iannucci was never going to limit himself to these shores. In , he adapted The Thick Of It for cinema and dropped hapless British government minister Tom Hollander into Washingtonrsquos then un-drained political swamp where he was pitted against boorish American general James Gandolfini. The film was called In The Loop and it won Iannucci an Oscar nomination.Three years later he created Veep for HBO. Starring former Seinfeld stalwart Julia Louis-Dreyfus as the US Vice President it took the TTOI format and tweaked it to create a hilarious political comedy which did for le in the West Wing what TTOI had done for the fictitious Department of Social Affairs and Citizenship . Veep is now in its seventh and final season and the previous six were all nominated for Emmy Awards. To date it was won , including Outstanding Comedy Series for the last three years running.So, itrsquos space next for Armando Iannucci, a place where no-one can hear you scream . Butthe Scot remains true to form, donrsquot think you wonrsquot be doing exactly that. Billy ConnollyWHAT makes Billy Connolly not only the greatest comedian in the UK, but the world  Wersquove long attached superlatives to his name, long tried to wonder what makes the Glaswegian so funny. There are those who cite Sir Billyrsquos surrealist streak and highlight how the former shipyard worker was influenced by the great Chic Murray.But what is it about Connolly thatrsquos allowed him to become a global superstar, a comedian, actor, documentary film maker and half decent banjo player  What defines him INSECURITY: All the great comedians are blessed with tragic insecurity and Connolly is no exception. It instils constant searching, an analysis of the world around which they keep trying to make sense of, in the hope that along the way it can provide comedy gold. ldquoI think my securities far outweigh my insecurities, he said. ldquoI am not nearly as afraid of myself and my imagination as I used to be.But that wasnrsquot always the case at all. Recalling the seven year-old schoolboy who fell in a puddle and was laughed at, Connolly realised that being mocked was far better than being beaten by nuns, or the Aunt who looked after him, or his father who sexually abused him. He knew then that escape from perpetual misery involved making people laugh and actually enjoyed his puddle moment. But he also knewhe were to become a comedian he would have to cultivate a personality, to ldquomake myself look windswept and interesting.It took time however. The quest involved the teenager experimenting with several worlds, from libraries to the Scouts, to cycling clubs to a religious group with whom he would travel to houses and read the Rosary to those ldquowaiting to watch the Beverly Hillbillies.CAMPERY: Even during his years in the shipyards, Connolly was never reluctant to draw attention to himself, with outrageous footwear and outfits so far away from the regulation Burton The Tailor two-piece. Later on, this inveterate show-offrsquos stage outfits were never quite a threat to Elton,but he came close. No opportunity was ever missed to surprise, whether appearing in lurex, banana boots or deck chair jackets. The result provided a delicious incongruity the insecure clown on stage telling jokes about his grim childhood, yet doing so with a continuous flick of highlighted hair, or a swish of the silky poncho.HAIR: Connolly certainly put his hair to good use. He has always had a very good head of it, which allowed him to leave the shipyard aged . Anyone with less hair would never have dared to enter the milieu that was the Scottish folk scene in the Sixties. The folk scene was really a front however for his true intent to follow Jimmy Logan and Stanley Baxter onto the entertainment circuit, and make the world laugh. But the hair suggested dferent characters he could be the urban philosopher, he could be a hippie, before later taking on a grander power and nailing his audience with the Crucixion.AWARENESS OF REALITY: Connolly was shaped, moulded, battered and plated by the experience of working as a boilerman in the shipyards, from the ages of -. Yet, while that provided reams of raw material for a comedy act, Connolly hadnrsquot yet worked up the courage to make the leap. Indeed, it took a colleague in the yards who told him to leave and never come back, to see him go off and pursue the dream.Connolly, however, was clever enough to know he wasnrsquot ready to go it alone and for a while held the hands of Humblebumsrsquo musicians Tam Harvey and Gerry Rafferty. And he was aware, that when matched with Rafferty, he was out of his depth. ldquoIrsquove got a voice like a goose farting in a tunnel, he admitted. ldquoAnd Gerry was very good for me. He taught me that I would never be a musician as long as my arse looked south. He was just so outstandingly good and getting better, and although I was getting better too, the space between us remained huge.BOLDNESS: Comedy, not folk music, was the future and success grew in Scotland with the release of his live albums. In , a taxi driver told Michael Parkinson how good the Big Yin was and he landed an invite. But how many comedians when offered the chance to appear on the biggest chat show in the land would tell a joke about we-murdering, sexual depravity and cheeky bicycle-parking  Connollyrsquos manager Frank Lynch figured this career was over before it really began. Wrong, Frank. So wrong.REFUSAL TO BE CONSTRAINED: If Billy Connolly once had to battle with an inferiority complex, being told he was useless by the aunt he lived with, he did a very good job of hiding it as his career rolled on. If anyone every bothered to tell him he could never become a playwright, he certainly didnrsquot listen.If anyone mentioned he couldnrsquot become a pop star, that too fell on deaf ears and he appeared on Top of The Pops several times with pastiches of Tammy Wynettersquos DIVORCE and the Village Peoplersquos In The Navy. .What was also apparent was Connolly wasnrsquot afraid to cause political upset, to create ide, at one time describing the newly devolved Scottish government as ldquoa pretendy wee parliament. The man who at one time owned homes in Aberdeenshire, New York and Malta, believed himself to be a citizen of the world. And somehow he got away with his critiques because, well, he was above it all.SOCIAL CHAMELEONISM: Connolly has been able to adapt to and fit in to a iety of worlds. His film career brought him into the orbit of the showbiz greats, the likes of Robin Williams and the Pythons, but far from feeling out of his depth, the Scot not only thrived but fed on his new source material. He discovered being Glaswegian could be a bonus. He made Glaswegians, for the first time, believe something very positive could come out of a housing scheme.WRITING: But itrsquos his comic writing that confirms the manrsquos genius. Aged , he moved to the Glasgow housing scheme, Drumchapel. He said later, ldquoDrumchapel is a housing estate just outside Glasgow. Well, itrsquos in Glasgow, but just outside civilisation. His similes are close to perfect. After appearing on the same bill as Elton John in the States in , the Scot was hit on the head with a pipe. ldquoThey made me feel as welcome as a fart in a spacesuit, he said later.HErsquoS A VARIETY ARTIST: While Connolly could come up with Chic Murray like aphorisms ndash ldquoMarriage is a great invention ndash but then so is the bicycle repair kit, or brilliant parodies such as the Crucixion, he has never been afraid to bend towards the Bernard Manning ldquoIf women are so bloody perfect at multi-tasking, how come they canrsquot have a headache and sex at the same time. Or how about: ldquoA biker goes to the doctor with hearing problems. lsquoCan you describe the symptoms to me rsquo lsquoYes. Homer is a fat yellow lazy b****** and Marge is a skinny bird with big blue hair!AND A PSYCHOLOGIST: Connolly offers big performance. No Rich Hall -side-of-mouth-jokes. He doesnrsquot just tell you a funny story. He throws it right onto your face. But he also understands and highlights the fragilities and complexities of the human condition, revealed with his line, "Never trust a man, who when left alone with a tea cosey doesnt try it on." Even his throwaway comments ldquoBigotry is a hobby in Glasgow canrsquot fail to resonate.SELF-DEPRECATION: He can be in your face and seemingly confident but knows his limits and when to rein it in. Connolly, for example, points out he is usually killed off in the first  minutes of his movies. But he can act as he revealed in Queen Victoria biopic Mrs Brown, a perfect vehicle for his ability to switch from aggression to tenderness in the flick of an eyelid. But itrsquos also hard to see past his deliciously quixotic role in  dark comedy What We Did On Our Holiday.HErsquoS A SALESMAN: Connolly has sold Glasgow to the world. Okay, it wasnrsquot a shortbread tin version of his hometown, more a rusty Spam tin, with bits of stale meat still inside, but he never, ever failed to make it funny. Where Joycersquos Ulysses transformed the image of Dublin from a backwater to a metropolis, Connolly too has sold his hometown, its colour and vibrancy, its humour as dark as a boilermakerrsquos overalls.HErsquoS A FIGHTER: Billy Connolly offers up the black comedy line, ldquoIrsquove got Parkinsonrsquos Disease. And I wish tae f*** hersquod take it back. But at the same time Sir Billy is entirely aware of the impact hersquos had on so many people. And so he should be. "Im very lucky in as much as I made a bit of a mark, and you think, well, I must have done something right.The Glasgow International Comedy Festival runs from March -.
