story: The business, which is no longer trading, will cease to exist from today and  employees will lose their jobs with immediate effect.:Fears over hundreds of Debenhams jobs in Scotland as  UK stores to closeHourstons is a well-known high street retailer in Ayr which was established  years ago and provided a broad offering of fashion, beauty, gts and furniture alongside a cafeacute.Linda Barr, Restructuring and Debt Advisory director at accountants French Duncan LLP, said: ldquoUnfortunately, this is a sign of the times and the very real changes which have occurred in the High Street."The High Street has become a much more hostile place for many traditional businesses as consumers sht their spending online leaving the centres of our towns and cities with large scale businesses suddenly missing essential customers. It is extremely dficult to turn around long-established businesses once sales start to fall and dficulties emerge.ldquoHourstons is an iconic brand in Ayrshire and its closure, and the loss of jobs, will be a dficult pill to swallow for the people and community of Ayr.Linda concluded: ldquoWe shall be selling off the assets of the business but, unfortunately, not as a going concern. The main property is currently being marketed as a development opportunity by CBRE and DM Hall and is unlikely to remain a retail site in the future.Eileen Blackburn, French Duncanrsquos Head of Restructuring and Debt Advisory, commented: ldquoHourstons battled against the changing retail environment but this is a story being told on the High Streets of many of our town and city centres as a lot of traditional retailers close because of major consumer changes.Eileen concluded: ldquoLocal councils need to look at ways to assist retailers, casual dining outlets and other stalwarts of the High Street to ensure that city centres remain attractive to consumers in the years to come.However, punitive business taxes and an inflexible approach by landlordsare leading to retail deserts in the heart of our communities.Local councils undoubtedly donrsquot want the destruction of our city centres to occur but donrsquot seem to be acting quickly enough to prevent further closures.

title: inside-diageos-edinburgh-johnnie-walker-experience-the-concept
story: The pound million Scotland-wide whisky tourism investment by the drinks giant includes roofbars, live music and theatre the experiences in the Princes Street flagship.:Roof-top bars and theatre part of Johnnie Walker whisky lsquoexperiencersquoThe move will create around  jobs and also see the upgrade of visitor facilities at distilleries which provide the malts for the Johnnie Walker blend.The refurbishment will retain features such as the clock at Binns corner, named after the original storeDiageo said it is investing in revamping its existing  distillery visitor attractions as wellreopening the ldquoiconic distilleries" of Port Ellen and Brora.The design statement, which inlcudes early-stage interior impressions,says the centre offers "a journey through  years of Johnnie Walker and Scotland".It includes an environmental experience that conveys how its distilleries "contribute the essence of their land and water sources"to create the flavour of Scotland.It also includes an interactive exploration of the whisky making process and opportunities to taste.The plan has flexible experiential spaces host dferent activations, including Fringe and other festival events, guest speakers and artists, and pop up installations from immersive innovators and cultural influencers.The roof-top experience will provide visitors with views across the city.Diageos Learning for Le Academy space will also provideflexibility for creative exploration and community programmes.Theprogrammewhich creates training and employment opportunities in the hospitality industry for unemployed people, and works to improve hospitality standards and promotes the responsible serving and consumption of alcohol.Diageo is investing over poundmin total in Scotch whisky experiences in Scotland. As well as the poundm for Edinburgh location and the transformation of its existing  distillery visitor attractions, afurtherpoundm investment will go to reopen Port Ellen and Brora distillers.

title: what-the-f-are-you-doing-im-one-of-you-brendan-rodgers-responds-to-celtic-fans-flak
story: Rodgers has been severely criticised by many fans for leaving the Parkhead club, who are bidding to win a historic treble treble, before the end of the season.Members of the ultra group The Green Brigade unfurled banners that described him as ldquoa fraud at their Ladbrokes Premiership game against Hearts on Wednesday night.And the Glasgow club described a video that showed fans singing vile chants about the Northern Irishman in a pub in Edinburgh before the match as ldquopathetic and disgusting.Speaking publicly for the first time since making the move to the East Midlands, Rodgers admitted he was aware of the backlash.However, he defended both his actions and his record during his  months in Scotland and described the abuse as ldquosad."Someone showed me the banner when I was at the Leicester Under- game, he said. ldquoOf course, it takes you aback a wee bit. But the supporters are hurting and I understand that.ldquoIts a shame, of course, because from the moment I walked into Celtic I gave my le to the club. I put everything into the training and preparation of the team. A lot of the people wouldnt know that."I havent seen the video, but I had heard there was something. I dont want that to be my final feeling of being at Celtic, especially when its your own."I dont want that to be the final measure of my work there. I gave much more than that.ldquoSo from the banner and the song  To be fair, like I said, I havenrsquot seen the stuff. Thatrsquos sad really. I can only put it down to hurt.ldquoI tend to focus more on the good side. Like I said, supporters will hurt and I get that. I understand that. Thatrsquos why Irsquoll never come out and kill them.Asked what he would say to the supporters who have pilloried him, Rodgers said: ldquoWhat the f*** are you doing  Bloody hell, Irsquom one of you. Okay, I made a career decision. It doesnrsquot make me any less of a Celt.ldquoIrsquom someone who turned up at half seven every morning of his le, was in there until all hours of the night, took over  games a season, preparing a team, changing a culture and a standard at a club, filling the support again.ldquoI tend to focus more on the good side. Like I said, supporters will hurt and I get that. I understand that. Thatrsquos why Irsquoll never come out and kill them.

title: tom-gordon-snps-currency-plan-may-please-members-but-not-voters
story: As shersquos been promising an update ldquoin a few weeks for almost half a year, that may be some time.But conference abhors a vacuum, so her SNP deputy Keith Brown has ridden to the rescue this weekend with a suspiciously fuzzy plan on a new currency after independence.If it was serious, it would be pitched at the electorate. It isnrsquot. Itrsquos pitched at an internal audience.In particular, itrsquos pitched at those many SNP members who are suspicious of the leadershiprsquos Growth Commission, the hair-shirt economic blueprint for an independent Scotland written by former MSP turned corporate lobbyist Andrew Wilson.A heresy against the  White Paper, the Commissionrsquos report recommended spending Decade One after a Yes vote driving down debt and keeping a tight grip on public spending. It also backed keeping the pound ndash at least for now.Ms Sturgeon declared herself delighted, the membership less so. Besides the whf of austerity, there was that plan to keep sterling and UK monetary policies. Former SNP MPs such as George Kerevan politely but firmly laid into it.After hosting a series of National Assemblies to hear the views of SNP members, Mr Brown will put a motion to Aprilrsquos conference backing most of the Commissionrsquos  recommendations, but with a more gung-ho line on currency.Writing for the home crowd in The National yesterday, Mr Brown said: ldquoWe will propose that it should now be party policy that an SNP government in an independent Scotland would establish an independent currency. So far, so clear. But then the fog descends.ldquoOf course, until that can be done safely and securely, our currency would continue to be the pound sterling. It must be done at the right time, in a way that affords necessary protection for our nationrsquos economy and for peoplersquos personal finances.ldquoThe aim of an SNP government would be to complete preparations in time for the newly independent Scottish Parliament, informed by assessments and information from the Central Bank, to take a decision on establishing a new currency by the end of its first term.ldquoThis will ensure that the use of sterling is not an open-ended commitment ndash an issue raised at the National Assemblies.The language is new. But at best, the leadership has moved from agnosticism on a new currency to a highly caveated inclination. Yet something that heavily caveated isnrsquot really a belief in anything. Itrsquos a fudge. Itrsquos also a muddle.For example, Mr Brown seems to suggest evidence and economics would count, but also that Holyrood would decide to back a currency on a set timetable regardless.A politically brave idea, as it would make the following election a referendum on whether to follow through with that decision.Mr Brown also reminds me of someone daydreaming about how theyrsquoll spend their lottery millions before theyrsquove even bought a ticket. It may be enjoyable, but therersquos the small matter of winning first. It was noticeable he didnrsquot offer a timetable on actually securing independence.The audience for this mush is clear from the last line, where he says activists at the partyrsquos National Assemblies didnrsquot like the idea of an open-ended commitment to sterling.They must be a conspiratorial lot. The Growth Commission never made an open-ended commitment to sterling. It said it should be used until something  made more sense, as did the SNP Governmentrsquos Fiscal Commission before the  referendum. Both said sterling was best initially because the UK and Scottish economies were so aligned.But both were open to a new currencythe economies erged. The Commission proposed six tests on credibility, markets, debt, trade, reserves , and public appetite. Explaining the process to voters before a referendum was an ldquoabsolutely necessity, it said. Both were also clear context was all. There was no dogmatism about having or not having a new Scottish currency. It all came down to the circumstances. They definitely did not say, lsquoLetrsquos do this in the first term of an independent parliament to keep the troops happy.rsquoBut it seems National Assembly-goers live in dread of an indefinite backstop on the currency, and want to put a time limit on it, whether itrsquos rational or not. How very ERG-like.I suspect that, behind the fudge, the SNP hierarchy is keeping faith with the Growth Commission, because it sees sense in it, while talking more warmly about a new currency to molly the members.This could backfire on several fronts. The members could see straight through it and get more disgruntled. It was interesting how much scepticism there was from senior SNP figures who want a new currency yesterday. The leadership is not trusted on this. Even vague talk of a new currency could become a giant bullseye for Unionists, who would use to it attack the SNP as reckless and flaky. The party has, after all, backed the euro, the pound, and now, sort of, a third currency.It does not seem driven by long-term national interest, but by short-term party management. The Tories have their Eurosceptics to placate, the SNP their sterling-sceptics.The key thing is whether it helps the cause. But who does this idea appeal to outside the  per cent Will a mystery currency move a single No voter to Yes  Did people reject independence because the last currency offer wasnrsquot radical enough  Did they object to their wages and pensions staying in sterling  Were they crying out to take a punt on a Scottish pound Mr Brown seems to think so. ldquoI believe this approach will maximize support for an independent Scotland, he wrote yesterday. I believe he may be disappointed.

title: first-minister-ready-to-work-with-other-parties-against-tories-brexit-plans
story: Askedshe would be prepared to form a Labour-SNP coalitionan election is triggered, Nicola Sturgeon said she would be "ready to work with other parties" to oppose the Conservatives Brexit plans.However, a spokesman for Scottish Labour said there would be "no deal, no pacts and no coalition with the SNP".She reiterated calls for Theresa May to rule out the UK leaving the EU without a deal and for a second Brexit referendum to be held.The SNP leader again pledged to set provide an update on the issue of a second Scottish independence referendum "within weeks".Askedshe would be willing to go into coalition with Labour at Westminsterthe results of a snap election enabled this, she told Greek newspaper Ta Nea: "We will be ready to contest any general electionone is called, and we would also be ready to work with other parties to oppose the Conservatives hugely damaging Brexit proposals."She said the Prime Ministers announcement of a vote on delaying the Brexit date until after March ,passed, opens the way for building the case for a second Brexit referendum."I believe such a vote would be justied because it has become increasingly clear that people did not have nearly enough information when they voted in  - and because the UK Government and Parliament have been completely unable to turn the Leave vote into a workable and deliverable deal", she said."Amid the chaos and confusion of Brexit, I think it is clearer than ever that Scotlands interests are not being served by a Westminster system that too often treats Scotland as an afterthought rather than an equal partner in the union."As First Minister, I will set out my thoughts on the issue of independence and a referendum in the coming weeks, once it becomes clearer what path the United Kingdom will go down."A Scottish Labour spokesman said: "We will be campaigning to win a majority at the next general election with policies to end austerity and invest in Scotland and the UK, and there will be no deals, no pacts and no coalition with the SNP."Labour has a credible plan to prevent a damaging Tory Brexit, and protect jobs and industries, so it was disappointing that the SNP abstained when we put it to a vote in the Commons in the week."

title: paul-hutcheon-scottish-labour-needs-a-leader-not-a-follower
story: The th century Russian novelistrsquos wise words could apply to Scottish Labour, perhaps the most dysal brood in UK politics.Richard Leonard heads to Dundee this week for his second party conference as leader. He wants to pitch himself as a potential First Minister and present his party as a united family to voters.Gary Smith, who leads a trade union that employed Leonard for more than  years, appears not to have been sent the harmony memo.CATCH UP: Smith blasts the state of Scottish LabourAccording to Smith, Scottish Labour has failed on Brexit and been weak on anti-Semitism. Damningly, he says Leonardrsquos strategy of ldquoriding on the coat-tails of Jeremy Corbyn wonrsquot work. In boxing terms, Smith has delivered a first-round knock-out.His analysis also happens to be shared by a growing body of opinion within Scottish Labour. I accept Leonard and Corbyn are close politically, but ideological similarities do not require a leader to surrender his autonomy and behave like a parrot.Brexit is his biggest failure. Leonard, much to the frustration of his MSPs and party members, has echoed Corbynrsquos Euroscepticism and opted to say as little as he can get away with on a second referendum. Both men want to strangle this option.Leonardrsquos hostility to a public vote is against the backdrop of over % of voters in Scotland supporting Remain in . Opinion polls show that backing for staying in the European Union has grown since the referendum. And yet, despite these facts, Leonard has bizarrely manoeuvred himself into the position of being the most pro-Brexit leader at Holyrood.His sleepy approach to the anti-Semitism row provides further evidence that his gut instinct is to defer to Corbyn. When the UK Labour leader resisted the full IHRA definition of anti-Semitism last year, Leonardrsquos response should have been swt and decisive.ldquoThe party should sign up to the IHRA and all the associated examples, without hesitation. We must make amends with the Jewish community, the statement should have read.Leonard instead gave a feeble interview to the BBC during which he offered warm words to Jews, but nothing . Corbyn eventually performed a U-turn and, asby magic, so did Leonard. It is clear some of his supporters believe the anti-Semitism scandal has been exaggerated to damage the Corbyn project.As a result of his back-seat leadership, Leonardrsquos fortunes are now tied to the electoral performance of Corbyn. He has failed to exercise the autonomy many of his predecessors worked so hard to extract from the UK party. His team is effectively a satellite of the Leader of the Oppositionrsquos Office at Westminster.He may also regret trying to use Corbyn as his meal ticket to Bute House, as there is little evidence of a ldquoJC bounce in Scotland. As Smith pointed out, although Scottish Labour made gains at the last general election, the party only put on , votes compared with the previous poll. Around , of these were in Edinburgh South, where Ian Murray was explicitly anti-Corbyn.Two rows are brewing that will inevitably fuel Labour faction-fighting. On Holyrood selections, Leonard allies want him to use his majority on the partyrsquos Executive to hand-pick List candidates for next Scottish Parliament election. Such a move would be brutal, and could inject fresh blood into a jaded group of MSPs, but it would backfireit was used to install middle aged under-achievers from the trade union movement.The partyrsquos ldquoorganisational review, led by deputy leader Lesley Laird, is the other potential flashpoint. Scottish Labour Kremlinologists see it as an attempt to restrict the power of general secretary Brian Roy and his team. Insiders say UK Labour is already micro-managing Scottish Labour finances in an unprecedented way.Leonard is a nice man. He has a big heart and was a more authentic representative of Labour values than Anas Sarwar, who he defeated for the leadership. But he is flailing and his party is heading towards another thumping defeat. Scottish Labour needs a leader, not a follower.

title: boost-for-theresa-may-as-key-tory-signals-brexit-support
story: Sir Graham Brady indicated he could swing behind the Prime Ministerrsquos Withdrawal Agreement ahead of crunch Commons votes as he expressed optimism about a breakthrough over the Northern Ireland backstop.Writing in the Mail on Sunday, Sir Graham said: ldquoThe whole country is tired of vacillation and delay.ldquoWhen the right compromise is offered, we should pull together behind the Prime Minister and help her to deliver our exit from the European Union on March .Many Brexiteers have expressed opposition to the backstop as it would leave the UK obeying EU customs rulesno wider trade deal is agreed after a transition period.Sir Graham, who branded the Governmentrsquos handling of the Brexit negotiations as ldquolions led by donkeys, indicated there was a growing mood for a deal in the Commons.He said:ldquoThis is not a time to make the best the enemy of the good, and most MPs are in a mood to compromise, but the danger of this backstop becoming permanent is a real one and it has to be tackled.ldquoMy conversations with senior diplomats and politicians from across Europe have given me cause for optimism that a breakthrough is near.ldquoThose who have pressed for delay or for no-deal to be taken off the table have weakened Theresa Mayrsquos hand and made a deal less likely, but I still believe a compromise is fundamentally in our interest and that of the EU.ldquoOnce we have that, my colleagues in Parliament need to recognise the strength of feeling.The comments came as the Sunday Times reported that the hardline European Research Groupof Tory MPs led by Jacob Rees-Mogg has drawn up ldquothree tests the Government must pass to win backing.In private talks with Attorney General Geoffrey Cox, the ERG called for a legally binding mechanism to escape the backstop, with a clear exit route and an unambiguous rewrite of the language in the Governmentrsquos legal advice, the newspaper said.The stance has been drawn up in conjunction with the DUP, according to the Sunday Times.The manoeuvring follows Mrs May telling MPs the Commons will have a ldquomeaningful vote on her Brexit plans by March .The PM said thather deal is rejected, MPs will be able to vote on whether the UK can leave the EU in a no-deal scenario, andthat is rejected, the Commons can decide on whether to extend Article  and delay Brexit.Meanwhile, EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said he does not believethe UK will have enough time to approve Mrs Mayrsquos withdrawal deal by the scheduled exit date of March .Mr Barnier suggested a ldquotechnical extension of up to two months may be needed.Askedhe thought it was possible to reach an agreement by March , evenWestminster gave the green light this month, Mr Barnier told Spainrsquos El Mundo newspaper: ldquoNo.

title: snp-accuses-tories-of-grubby-brexit-bung-with-more-cash-for-northern-ireland
story: The funds are on top of the pound billion-plus block grant allocated under the Barnett model for devolved regions.Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley said on Thursday the money recognises the lack of opportunity for ldquofundamental service reconfiguration in the current financial year.The SNP has demanded to know when Scotland will receive a comparable share of extra cash, saying an equivalent share for the country ndash which has a larger population than Northern Ireland ndash would be pound million.The party has accused the Conservative Government of ldquodelivering a grubby Brexit bung to buy off DUP votes ahead of crucial votes on Brexit this month.UK ministers have insisted the pound million is to address specic challenges in Northern Ireland.SNP economy spokeswoman Kirsty Blackman has written to Scottish Secretary David Mundell, asking ious questions about the funding.The letter asks him: ldquoWhy do you support additional money for Northern Ireland but not a proportionate increase in funding for Scotland Commenting later, Ms Blackman, the MP for Aberdeen North, said: ldquoThe Tories are delivering another bung for the DUP, ripping up the rule book in the process.ldquoButthe rules are to be applied as they should be, then Scotlandrsquos fair share would amount to an extra pound million for public services here.this additional funding will not result in Barnett consequentials for Scotland. To suggest it should is to fail to understand how the Barnett formula works.ldquoThis problem lies at the door of David Mundell, who has disgracefully failed to fight Scotlandrsquos corner right the way through the Brexit process.ldquoThis extra cash for Northern Ireland comes just before Theresa May brings her bad Brexit deal back to Parliament ndash where every MPrsquos vote will count.ldquoAnd it is crystal clear that the Tories are delivering a grubby Brexit bung to buy off DUP votes whilst Scotlandrsquos voice in the Brexit process is ignored.A UK Government spokeswoman said: ldquoLike previous Northern Ireland support packages, or funding for city and growth deals in Scotland, the pound million funding addresses specic challenges.ldquoAs there has been no increase inspending on devolved matters in England, this additional funding will not result in Barnett consequentials for Scotland. To suggest it should is to fail to understand how the Barnett formula works.

title: graduate-apprenticeship-target-rises-to-1300-places
story: The  target for the current financial year was exceeded, and Fair Work Secretary Derek Mackay announced it will rise by  for  .Skills Development Scotland develops the apprenticeships along with industry, and further and higher education, to enable workers to study up to Masterrsquos degree level.Apprenticeships on offer include subjects such as engineering, business, IT and cyber security ndash and will expand to include data science this year.The vast majority of Scotlandrsquos universities offer graduate apprenticeship places, with Aberdeen University a recent recruit.Mr Mackay said: ldquoApprenticeships are a vital piece of the jigsaw to improve Scotlandrsquos productivity, benefiting iniduals, employers and the wider economy.ldquoThat is why we are investing in more apprenticeship opportunities than ever before, ensuing more people benefit from work-based learning.ldquoWe remain firmly on track to achieve our ambitious target of , new apprenticeship starts by , with a focus on higher level apprenticeships.ldquoBy increasing the number of Graduate Apprenticeships available for   to more than ,, more people will have the opportunity to study while they earn and gain first-hand experience of their industry.Skills Development Scotland chief executive Damien Yeates said: ldquoWe continues to work with business to increase the number of new apprenticeship jobs through Modern and Graduate opportunities ndash creating skills that meet their needs.ldquoScottish apprenticeships now allow employers to introduce young people to their business while they are still at school and keep them in their workforce until they are degree qualied.

title: johnstone-and-harvie-to-share-green-leadership-duties-at-holyrood
story: Patrick Harvie is to be joined in the role by Lothian MSP Alison Johnstone.The decision to name the pair as co-leaders of the parliamentary group follows a meeting of the partyrsquos national council, which approved the move.The party said Ms Johnstone and Mr Harvie will share leadership responsibilities at Holyrood, such as speaking at First Ministerrsquos Questions, which Ms Johnstone will do for the first time on Thursday.She said: ldquoIrsquom pleased to have this opportunity to share the parliamentary leadership role with Patrick..@AlisonJohnstone and @patrickharvie have today been confirmed as the Co-Leaders of the Scottish Greens Parliamentary Group following a meeting of the Scottish Green Party National Council. pic ScjSBDanImmdash Scottish GreensMarch , ldquoThe Green MSPs have continually punched above our weight, leading the change in Scotland, and I am sure we will continue to do so in the years ahead.ldquoGreens have gender-balanced leadership roles throughout the party and I am pleased that this will now be the case in Parliament too.Maggie Chapman will remain a co-convener of the partyrsquos national council.Mr Harvie, a Glasgow MSP, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that the party has agreed that Alison and I can share the role of parliamentary leader.ldquoAlison has done fantastic work in Parliament, from winning progressive changes to Scottish social security legislation to her role as a powerful advocate for animal welfare.ldquoShersquoll be a great parliamentary co-leader and wersquoll be working closely together to make sure the Greens keep leading the change in Scotland.

title: mundell-and-carlaw-urge-backing-for-pms-deal-to-leave-eu
story: Scottish Secretary David Mundell and Jackson Carlaw, the Scottish Conservative partyrsquos interim leader, described the deal to leave the EU as ldquothe right plan for Britain and Europe.The SNP described the pairrsquos support for the deal as ldquosickening, saying every Brexit outcome will see Scotland worse off.The Conservative politicians spoke out just days after Prime Minister Theresa May accepted that the UK may not leave the EU on March , offering MPs a chance to vote to delay Brexither deal is rejected again later this month.Mr Mundell and Mr Carlaw said: ldquoThe time for debating and negotiating is nearly over. The time to decide is here. Our clear position is that, over the coming days, MPs should decide to back the Prime Ministerrsquos Brexit deal.ldquoIt delivers on the decision the country made. It hands back control of our money, laws and borders.ldquoIt gives us control over our waters, offering us the chance to revitalise our fishing sector. And, while we will be able to strike new trade deals around the world, the deal will also set the basis for a strong and abiding new friendship with our allies across the continent.ldquoItrsquos the right plan for Britain and Europe. Supporting it will mean we can all move on to meet the pressing and urgent challenges we all face.Meanwhile, at Holyrood, a Scottish Government debate on the EU withdrawal negotiations is scheduled to take place on Tuesday.The senior Conservatives claimed First Minister Nicola Sturgeon will be making ldquoone last attempt to wring yet more grievance out of Brexit and boost support for Scottish independence.Mr Mundell and Mr Carlaw added: ldquoThe best way now to stop the SNPrsquos separatist games is to back the deal, leave the EU in a smooth and orderly fashion, so we can all get back to the real task of creating a fairer, more prosperous United Kingdom.The SNPrsquos Europe spokesman Stephen Gethins responded: ldquoThe Prime Ministerrsquos deal is bad for Scotland and the support from the Scottish Tories is sickening ndash they are clearly rattled and saying anything to try and deflect from their shambolic handling of Brexit.ldquoThey have no higher ambition for Scotland than meekly accepting whatever Brexit disaster awaits the UK. Or as one of Mr Mundellrsquos own Cabinet colleagues put it ndash lsquoOnce yoursquove hit the iceberg, yoursquore all on it together.rsquoldquoEvery single Brexit outcome will see Scotland worse off ndash our nation overwhelmingly rejected Brexit at the ballot box and it beggars belief that Tory MPs and MSPs could advocate backing a botched deal that would see jobs, living standards and household incomes slashed and threatens the growth of our economy.ldquoThere is a better future for Scotland, as an independent nation, and the fiasco of Brexit only serves to show how Scotlandrsquos interests are ignored by Westminster.

title: sanders-calls-for-political-revolution-as-he-launches-2020-campaign
story: Speaking just miles from the rent-controlled apartment where he grew up in Brooklyn, Mr Sanders forcefully made the case that he is nothing like fellow New Yorker Mr Trump.He told a crowd: ldquoMy experience as a child, living in a family that struggled economically, powerfully influenced my le and my values. I know where I came from.ldquoAnd that is something I will never forget.The Democrats in the  race have taken ied approaches to Mr Trump, with some avoiding saying his name entirely, while others make implicit critiques of his presidency.Mr Sanders has never shied from attacking Mr Trump in stark terms, and during his speech at Brooklyn College he called the US leader ldquothe most dangerous president in modern American history and said Mr Trump wants to ldquoide us up.The Vermont senator positioned himself in opposition to Trump administration policies from immigration to climate change.Beyond the issues themselves, Mr Sanders, who grew up in the Jewish neighbourhood of Flatbush in a middle-class family, drew a stark contrast between himself and the billionaire in the White House who hails from Queens.ldquoI did not have a father who gave me millions of dollars to build luxury skyscrapers, casinos and country clubs, said Mr Sanders, who has lived in Vermont for decades.Mr Sanders also said he ldquodid not come from a family of privilege that prepared me to entertain people on television by telling workers: lsquoYoursquore fired.ldquoI came from a family who knew all too well the frightening power employers can have over every day workers.As he began his speech, Mr Sanders hinted at how he sees the race ndash a campaign that runs beyond the key battlegrounds. ldquoThis is a -state campaign, he said. ldquoWe will not concede a single state to Donald Trump.

title: jeremy-corbyn-urged-to-join-other-party-leaders-in-pushing-for-brexit-poll
story: The leader of the Liberal Democrats, Sir Vince Cable, and the Westminster heads of the SNP and Plaid Cymru, Ian Blackford and Liz Saville Roberts, have written to Mr Corbyn, inviting him to a joint meeting.The move follows Labours sht in favour of backing a new referendum on Brexit.Sir Vince said: "Opposition leaders have been meeting for several months working together to secure a Peoples Vote."Now that Labour has decided to support giving people the final say, Jeremy Corbyn should join us, so we can work together and stop Brexit."I hope Jeremy Corbyn doesnt waste any more time. He must do the right thing and join the Liberal Democrats in offering the people an exit from this Tory mess."Ms Saville Roberts said: "Labour have a face for all occasions, but now theyve run out of masks."Jeremy Corbyn must now follow his own policy and back a Peoples Vote or face being the midwe of Brexit."Opposition MPs have worked together for months. title: the-seuss-the-whole-seuss-and-nothing-but-the-seuss
story: IF you look back on your le yoursquoll be surprised to discover just how deeply Ted Geisel is embedded in the heart and soul of your family. For me, it started with my grandmother teaching me to read at the local library the summer before I went to primary school. She chose books by Geisel - beloved around the world under his pen name, Dr Seuss. Green Eggs and Ham, and The Cat in the Hat set me up for a lelong love affair with the written word.I taught my own children to read with Dr Seuss, and to this day my two daughters and I still read The Grinch together every Christmas Eve. Theyrsquore  and . They tell me theyrsquoll read the same books to their children, and I imagine in years to come those children reading Seuss to their own sons and daughters long after Irsquom gone.After I published my first novel, I began writing stories for my children, but I soon realised Irsquod never have the magic of Seuss - whorsquos been called the Milton, the Renoir, of childrenrsquos writing. So I began studying the le of Ted Geisel - I wanted to know what shaped this genius.Itrsquos a good time to tell his story: yesterday was Dr Seuss Day, when hersquos celebrated around the world, and Thursday is World Book Day - an excuse for children to dress up as their favourite literary characters. Unsurprisingly, the Cat in the Hat is one of the most ubiquitous outfits.Ted was a complex man, his soul could be as light as a childrsquos, yet his le - which charted the th century and took in many of its great themes such as war, wealth, race and changing social values - was often full of the pain of adulthood.He was born into a wealthy immigrant German family in the town of Springfield, Massachusetts, in , and named Theodore Seuss Geisel. Itrsquos thought Matt Groening, creator of The Simpsons, set his anarchic cartoon in a fictional Springfield in homage to Seuss. From the very beginning, Tedrsquos le was a mix of word-play and imagination. The brewery his father owned - Kalmbach and Geisel - was known locally as lsquoCome Back and Guzzlersquo, and his mother, from a family of bakers, sang weird nonsense songs to him about pies.His father helped run the local zoo, and encouraged Ted to draw the animals he saw there. Tedrsquos pictures were strange caricatures - with too many knuckles, or spindly legs. His first character came from one of these lsquozoo drawingsrsquo - a beast with ears nine foot long which he called a lsquowynnmphrsquo.His niece Peggy Owens - who was as close to Seuss as a daughter - said: lsquoHe never lost the ability to see things through the eyes of a child.rsquo That ability to retreat into a world of imagination became more important to Ted as he got older. When the First World War broke out, Ted found himself bullied by other children because of his German roots and with the coming of prohibition in peace time, the family brewery was closed.Ted was no great scholar but he excelled at English, and after school he went on to Dartmouth College. While there, he spent most of his time writing for the collegersquos magazine Jack-O-Lantern - which carried cartoons and comic stories. Classes forgotten, hersquod be found in the morning, sleeping at his editorial desk. His niece Peggy said: lsquoHe simply never stopped playing hookey from the real world.rsquoA run-in with the law over a gin party during prohibition saw him banned from the magazine. But Ted got round the punishment by writing under a nom de plume: Seuss. Phyllis Cerf Wagner - the actress, socialite and writer who married Tedrsquos publisher Bennet Cerf, and was instrumental in the shaping of the Seuss legend - said: lsquoHe took his motherrsquos maiden name, Seuss, as he was saving Geisel for when he wrote the great American novel.rsquoFor now, though, the dizzying heights of literature were to evade him. He went to Oxford University in the hope of becoming an English professor, but dropped out. He spent most of his time at Oxford doodling in his notebook - which brought him to the attention of a bright young American woman called Helen Palmer. Looking over his shoulder in a lecture, she saw one of his pictures - a flying cow - and told him he should become an illustrator. Not long after, they ed to America and married. Helen was less a muse and more a mentor - she encouraged and helped shape his work, and she brought order to his le.Ted was no party animal - he was shy, nervous in public, and liked the company of close friends not big groups, though he did love a vodka on the rocks and plenty of cigarettes - however, the strictures of adulthood were not for him. Without Helen, it was said, he wouldnrsquot have been able to balance a chequebook.Ted became a jobbing cartoonist and by now had added lsquoDrrsquo to his pen-name - an in-joke about the doctorate hersquod failed to get at Oxford. His big break came by chance. In the s, Flit was a popular brand of fly-spray. Ted drew a one-off cartoon for Judge magazine showing a medieval knight who canrsquot sleep because therersquos a dragon in his bedroom. The punch line reads: lsquoDarn it all, another dragon. And just after I sprayed the whole castle with Flit.rsquoHe was hired on the spot to do all Flitrsquos ads. lsquoThis became one of the most successful advertising campaigns in history,rsquo one of his biographers, Janet Pascal, says. Financially comfortable, Ted now turned his attention towards his lelong ambition: writing and illustrating childrenrsquos books.Ted was infamous in his family for exaggeration - he was always embellishing the truth . His first big success was more than a little autobiographical. The book lsquoAnd to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Streetrsquotells the story of a child out for a walk who imagines a fantastical adventure. A suburban afternoon becomes filled with make-believe giraffes, magicians, police - and a man with a ten foot beard.Initially, publishers turned the book down - it didnrsquot have a moral, they said - but finally it was bought and in  became a critical hit. Beatrix Potter was a fan, saying she adored lsquothe truthful simplicity of the untruthfulnessrsquo.Publicly, Tedrsquos le was on the up, but privately there was much sadness. His mother died before seeing his success, and his beloved sister Marnie drted into alcoholism and died whilst estranged from Ted. He and his we also learned they couldnrsquot have children. Ted would later invent an imaginary child lsquoChrysanthemum-Pearlrsquo and heartbreakingly dedicate a book to her. His friend and biographer Judith Morgan said: lsquoPart of his protection was to not allow himself to spend his le in grief, and perhaps thatrsquos why he found such joy in doing the outrageous books he did.rsquoHis next successful book, Horton Hatches The Egg, added the morality that Mulberry Street was seen to lack. It tells the story of an elephant, Horton, who finds an egg, abandoned by its mother, and sits on it in the hope of hatching it, in the face of threats and even the risk of being shot. lsquoShootyou must,rsquo says Horton, lsquoI wonrsquot run away. I meant what I said and I said what I meant, an elephant is faithful,  per cent.rsquoIt was a smash hit. Tedrsquos editor, Michael Frith, said: lsquoIn the hands of a gted preacher therersquos nothing more powerful than a great lesson.rsquoHorton appeared in . As war loomed, it would be seven years before Ted wrote another book. lsquoWhile Paris was being occupied by the clanking tanks of the Nazis,rsquo Ted said, lsquoI could no longer keep my mind on drawing pictures of Horton the elephant.rsquoToo old to fight, Ted enlisted and became a captain in one of the most remarkable propaganda outfits ever - the US armyrsquos First Motion Picture Unit. He worked with Mel Blanc , Chuck Jones , and Frank Caprachurning out films like Private Snafu - army slang for lsquoSituation Normal: All F****d Uprsquo - to boost the war effort.After the war, there was a social panic over the effect of TV on childrenrsquos literacy. Ted was challenged by his publisher to write a story for children learning to read using just  simple words. The limitations were tortuous but after a yearrsquos labour The Cat in the Hat was born - the story of a trickster cat who causes havoc in the lives of two young children.The book has been poured over by literary scholars. Itrsquos been subjected to Freudian analysisand to racial interpretations . To most, it simply captures the anarchy of childhood. Janet Schulman, an editor who worked closely with Ted, said: lsquoHe allowed a childrsquos imagination to guide him.rsquoTed was now re-writing the rules of how children learned to read. With Green Eggs and Ham, he reduced the number of words in the book to just  - making it a perfect primer - and was hailed as the saviour of childrenrsquos literacy, replacing stale Peter and Jane with the crazy Fox in Socks.Now the most important childrenrsquos author in the world, Tedrsquos stories became more political. The Sneetches savages American racism The Butter Battle Book mocks the Cold War The Lorax is an environmentalist fable. His politics often upset conservative America.In , after struggling with ill health, and depression over Tedrsquos affair with Audrey Stone Dimond, a friend of the family, Helen took her own le. Ted married Audrey less than a year later.Tedrsquos last book is one of his most loved - Oh, the Places Yoursquoll Go. Itrsquos Tedrsquos joyous take on le - his valediction to readers young and old. His agent, Jed Mattes, said it was lsquolike a wise grandfather sitting down and talking to a younger generationrsquo.In his last days, Ted, too unwell to make it to his bedroom, slept in his studio. He died in , just a few feet from his drawing board. After his death, the students of his old college, Dartmouth, recited his works for a full day, as a mark of respect to a man who had single-handedly shaped their childhood, and the collective childhood of us all.

title: Iain Macwhirter  28 days to go and Westminster won   t even reject no deal  let alone back a People   s Vote
story: I could give you a pious expression of naive hope. Tell you that therersquos going to be a referendum on Brexit, that the ERG are back in their box, Jezza has finally come good, and Theresa May has been put in a secure unit. But I canrsquot in all honesty agree with commentators, like the blessed Polly Toynbee, who believe we are now on the road to redemption.Yes, Labour did repeat its promise to hold a referendumJeremy Corbynrsquos ldquoworkable plan of a permanent customs union is rejected ndash as it was in one of last weekrsquos many meaningless votes. Oh, and Labour will support a referendumthere is no General Election. Anda no deal Tory deal looks likely. If, , .ButLabour really wanted to eliminate the threat of no deal, it would have moved heaven and earth to deliver the SNPrsquos motion calling for precisely that.Looking back on this dismal week, the standout, surely, is the arrant insanity of Parliament ndash a rational body of elected representatives ndash failing to take the opportunity to rule out an event which would put the army on the streets, interrupt food and medicine supplies, and cause the loss of tens of thousands of jobs.Yes, the Yvette Cooper Oliver Letwin amendmentwas endorsed by Parliament overwhelmingly, after Theresa May gave it the nod. This means that there will be an extension to Article Parliament doesnrsquot support a deal by March . Well and good. If therersquos one thing the UK Parliament is supremely good at itrsquos failing to agree.It doesnrsquot like Mayrsquos botched deal, the Norway option, EFTA or any other solution that Brussels thinks acceptable. So that means an extension is inevitable. Except that the French president Emmanuel Macron and the Brussels negotiator, Michel Barnier, have made clear that the  countries of the EU , will only contemplate delaying Britainrsquos departure from the EUit is for ldquoa purpose. Holding more meaningless votes, staging more ministerial resignations and arguing on College Green outside Parliament do not, one suspects, constitute a legitimate purpose.Still, everyone seems convinced that an extension is in the bag. This led to largely unwarranted excitement on the Remain side. With Labour calling for a Peoplersquos Voteand Theresa Mayrsquos deadline finally breached, Twitter went into orbit. Lord Adonis all but declared victory in the Battle of Brexit. Europhiles were dancing in the streets, metaphorically at least, and jeering at the nasty Brexiters who had been defeated by the forces of good. It was like the last reel of Lord of the Rings.But such triumphalism was premature. Much as I wish it were the case, there is still no majority in Parliament for a referendum. Stephen K Bush, the political editor of the New Statesman, has been counting them out and counting them back in again and he is adamant that the Labour Brexit rebels will prevent any motion for a referendum passing through Parliament. He says at least  Labour MPs are opposed. Hersquos right.ldquoRebels here is something of a misnomer since there is widespread belief that Brexit is the outcome desired by their leader. Indeed, on one interpretation of last weekrsquos events, Jeremy Corbyn has managed to find a way to secure Brexit while also appearing to support a referendum. This is because what is called the Kyle Wilson amendment.This cross-party proposal, which Labour is minded to support on March , calls for MPs to agree to Theresa Mayrsquos deal , but only on the condition that there is a referendum to validate it. Bingo. Labour can tell all its working-class Brexit supporters in target marginals that, yes, it didnrsquot block Brexit. But Jeremy can also curry favour with the Remainiacs of Islington by appearing to support a Peoplersquos Vote.Itrsquos very clever, but to my mind somewhat bonkers. Why would Labour help pass Theresa Mayrsquos deal, which Jeremy Corbyn has said is worse than no deal, would lose thousands of jobs and would lock the UK into a backstop from which it cannot escape  At least this is what he has said repeatedly in the Commons.Surely, a vote is a vote. Theresa May could legitimately say that her deal has been endorsed by Parliament, and call on Labour to campaign for it in any referendum. Not that she has the slightest intention of calling a referendum.Theresa Mayrsquos strategy is the same as it ever was: not listening, nothing has changed, take it or leave it. It pains me to say it, but the Prime Minister at least has a strategy. It is to run down the clock, while allowing the ious tribes in Parliament and in her Cabinet, to fall out among themselves.Itrsquos working. Labour is moving ever more in the direction of her deal, however much they may deny it. Parliament canrsquot agree on anything.There are tears in Cabinet and more resignations ndash  from the Government so far. But whorsquos counting  The European Research Group ndash that comically misnamed faction of extreme Brexiters ndash has reportedly split over William Rees-Moggrsquos equivocation on the Irish backstop.And while all about is chaos and acrimony, so ticks away the clock until Brexit day. Twenty-eight days at the time of writing. Goodness me, is that really the time  Yes it is. As in the film of the same name, the zombies are stirring.I accept that is an offensive way to describe Nigel Faragersquos ldquoBrexit Betrayal march from Sunderland to London. But it could get nasty on the road.What do I think will happen in the end  As Irsquove been saying in this column since Christmas, I think Parliament will block a no-deal Brexit. There will be an extension of Article , and Labour will probably end up backing Mayrsquos deal, or abstaining on it which amounts to the same thing.If Labour, by some remote chance, continues to reject Mayrsquos deal or its iants, in the meaningful vote on the inglorious twelfth, then I think MPs would still reject a referendum. There is still no majority for one, and Labourrsquos die-hard Brexiters are not for turning.Which makes the most likely option ndash about the only one Theresa May can authorise as PM under her prerogative powers ndash would be to revoke Article . Pull the plug. End it.OK, so thatrsquos wishful thinking on my part. Her Government would fall and precipitate an election. But looking at the chaos that is Brexit, and the lack of time, it seems as good a shout as any, especiallyBrussels reject a meaningless extension.If Britain canrsquot decide how to leave the EU, an extension to Article  would be pointless. The sensible thing to do would be to cancel Brexit, go away, and think again.

title: scottish-universities-received-over-400m-in-fees-from-students-in-despotic-regimes
story: Higher education institutions have received nearly poundm from Chinese scholars in the last three years and around poundm from students in Saudi Arabia, which is regarded by critics as an international pariah.Russians have ploughed in another poundm to universities, which compete in a tough market for international students.One critic believes the sums raise questions about universities entering into partnerships with the autocracies.However, a spokesperson for Universities Scotland, which represents higher education institutions, said: ldquoUniversities educate, inform, create knowledge, encourage rational debate and challenge received wisdom. Every country can benefit from graduates who have developed these attributes.Saudi Arabia, an oil rich dictatorship, was widely condemned last year over the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.The columnist was lured to the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, where he was murdered and dismembered by a hit squad.One of the suspects is Dr Salah Muhammad al-Tubaigy, a forensic pathologist who specialises in autopsies, and who allegedly used his skills to dismember Khashoggi.A number of media outlets, including the Herald, reported that he used to study at Glasgow University, prompting rector Aamer Anwar to urge the institution to ldquobreak all links with the Kingdom.Other than the Khashoggi scandal, a recent report by Amnesty International stated that Saudi Arabia ldquoseverely restricts freedom of expression, association and assembly. Its bombing of Yemen has also been condemned.The Herald on Sunday asked universities how much they had received in tuition fees - both undergraduate and postgraduate - from students from Saudi Arabia and other despotic regimes.Twelve institutions have taken in over poundm since  from Saudi students, with Glasgow University leading the way on pound.m.Glasgowrsquos website states: ldquoThe university has a long-established relationship with Saudi Arabia and we have been welcoming students here for many decades.In second place is Strathclyde University, which received over poundm from students from the same country.Strathclyde Universityrsquos website states: ldquoStrathclyde has a long history of welcoming students from Saudi Arabia.Edinburghs total stands at around pound.m. The same university accepted around poundm from a foundation created by Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, a member of the Saudi royal family, to establish an Islamic study centre.However, Scottish universities have received a far larger sum, nearly poundm, from Chinese students. Edinburgh benefited to the tune of poundm over three years, while Glasgow took in pound.m.According to the latest Amnesty report, China continues to draft new laws that present ldquoserious threats to human rights.The same report stated that the regime has strict controls on internet use, represses religious activities and attacks freedom of expression in Hong Kong.Ten universities received over poundm in fees from Russia-based students, with Edinburgh again topping the fee list.Vladimir Putinrsquos autocratic leadership has been marked by crackdowns on opposition politicians, as well as assassinations in the UK. Putin critics have long argued that regime-friendly oligarchs have spent their wealth in countries such as the UK.There is no suggestion that students should be blamed for the actions of their rules, but campaigners believe the amount of money involved raises wider questions.Andrew Smith of Campaign Against Arms Trade said: "International students shouldnt be punished for the atrocities and abuses of their governments, nor should they be treated as a revenue stream for underfunded universities.ldquoHowever,the universities themselves are entering into official government partnerships or offering support to the regimes then questions need to be asked.ldquoThe Chinese, Russian and Saudi dictatorships all have utterly appalling human rights records, and Scottish universities should ensure they arent doing anything that could indicate support for them or legitimise them."MSP Ross Greer, the Scottish Greens education spokesperson said: ldquoThere is a massive dference between placing sanctions on those directly associated with a criminal regime and preventing all students from say Saudi Arabia from studying here.ldquoWhat we cannot allow is dependence on income from these students turning into institutional tolerance for oppressive regimes. The worrying trend towards closer links with the Chinese government for example, through its Confucius propaganda programme, should concern everyone in Scotland."

title: settlement-was-offered-three-years-earlier-to-glasgow-city-council
story: Stefan Cross of Action  Equality Scotland, which represents the majority of the , mainly female workers who secured the mammoth settlement in January, said he approached the council in June  with the intention of bringing an end to the long-running dispute.ldquoWe had a short meeting with [then council leader] Frank McAveety and [HR director] Robert Anderson to discuss the possibility of resolving these matters, he said.ldquoThe basis was thatthey paid our clients what we thought they were entitled to under payment protection we would end the legal proceedings.ldquoOur estimate was that it would be about pound million but we would have to very the figures as we hadnrsquot seen the pay data.ldquoThat was the nature of the discussion it was us making a presentation trying to break the log-jam and them not responding at all. We didnrsquot succeed - thank god for that.At that time, the council had won an employment tribunal case saying that a job evaluation process it had completed a decade previously was sound. An appeals tribunal, however, had ruled that its practice of protecting bonuses that had previously been earned by male staff only was discriminatory.While the women were appealing the first decision and the council the second, Mr Cross said he would have been willing to draw a line under all proceedings to settle the payment protection part only.ldquoStatistically, therersquos only a % chance of overturning a tribunal decision so we knew there was a massive risk that we would lose the appeal - it was much more likely that we would lose than we would win, he said.ldquoWe thought we wouldnrsquot win until we got to the Supreme Court, although we didnrsquot even knowwe would get the possibility to get to the Supreme Court.ldquoWe didnrsquot know we would win at the Court of Session - that was the risk we were running - but it happened to be that we got a bench that clicked.After losing both appeals the council, which passed from Labour to minority SNP control in May , agreed to settle the claims, with the poundm deal being agreed this January after a year of negotiations. To help foot the bill the local authority, which will increase council tax by % this year, is mortgaging a portfolio of properties including the Riverside Museum and SEC Armadillo, with the annual cost of servicing that debt expected to run into tens of millions of pounds.Mr McAveety and Glasgow City Council both confirmed that the informal and unminuted meeting with Action  Equality took place, although they denied that the poundm figure had been discussed.ldquoThis did not happen, a council spokesman said. ldquoRepresentatives of ActionEquality restated their position that the council should stop defending equal-pay claims.ldquoHowever, officers are clear that no offer was made and that figure was not put to the council.Mr McAveety said that while he personally would have been in favour of negotiating an end to the dispute, his hands were tied by council officials who wanted to follow legal process.ldquoSenior officials said lsquothis is in the courts and therersquos been an employment tribunal ruling that has favoured the councilrsquo, he said.ldquoThe general discussion [at the meeting] was around the issue of the number of folk that Action  Equality were representing, an observation on the role of the trade unions and, from Stefan Crossrsquos point of view, that we should try to settle.ldquoIt was left to Robert Anderson and the chief executive [Annemarie OrsquoDonnell] to deal with and I never came back [to Action  Equality] because I thought there was no authorisation from the council.The eventual bill for the local authority is signicantly higher than Mr Crossrsquos original estimate because, in addition to the number of claimants more than doubling since June , it is compensating affected workers for having their jobs undervalued as well as for not being able to share in bonuses.The poundm figure covers the period from , when the discredited pay system was put in place, to either  or , with a further settlement expected to be negotiated to cover the period from that end point to when a new system is put in place.The new scheme is not expected to be implemented until  at the earliest, with , inidual jobs having to be assessed, compared and signed off by both the council and the womenrsquos union representatives first.The staff who are part of the claim are expected to start receiving their cash in the summer, with average payments in the region of pound,.

title: from-the-royal-mint-to-pure-minted-the-alphabet-of-scotland
story: From the Angel of the North to Zebra crossings, the coins will be an A-Z of quintessential Britishness.The Loch Ness Monster will takes its place at ldquoL, which sparked a small debate in The Herald on Sunday offices over whether it should have appeared at ldquoN, for Nessie.So, in celebration of Nessie, Ron McKay has come up with his own list of quintessentially Scottish suggestions:A is for Arbroath, and the declaration of: Itrsquos what the home teamrsquos keeper exclaimed last month when his goal kick into a gale at Gayfield, on the lip of the North Sea, ended up as a corner for the other team with the ball eventually landing in Carnoustie.B is for Baw or Barsquo: Used as a prefix to a transportation receptacle, slang for male genitalia, and as a suffix for fit, and a game involving a leathern sphere wersquore notably bad at. Sometimes the former has one heid tacked on. This is not, as you might think, an approving nod to a large brain, but a term of abuse. About which much more down the letters. Itrsquos also for Buckfast, the national drink of our impoverished youth. And Big Yin, who hasnrsquot touched the stuff in years.C is for Cauld: What your Bs getyoursquore a man wearing the correct dress under the kilt. Women, I am reliably informed, are not bound by the same strict dress code. The word is often also led by an active adjective which is old English slang for fornication.D is for Dreich: That cold clammy spell that descends when Derek Mackay gets to his feet in the Parliament. The manrsquos a climate changer unto himself. When he strolls through Princes Street Gardens healthy plants, deprived of the light, shrivel and die.E is for Eck: The finest politician to bestride our wee country,he does say it himself. No more, then, about him as his lawyers read this. Or,you prefer and yoursquore spiteful, itrsquos for Eejit, although obviously not applying to the foregoing titan . But itrsquos liberally used where, normally about politicians.F is for First Minister. And Fandango, which is a complicated process, a dance that Wee Nicola has got herself into, which involves terpsichorean political manoeuvres to avoid becoming partnered once more with Eck, in his ongoing travails.G is for Gallus. And Ginger: Of the latter therersquos a few, with Green Ross Greer heading the queue. By this time next year hersquoll even have started shaving. Itrsquos also Neil Lennon, who at the time of writing is Celticrsquos new manager, and is the very definition of short-fused combustibility. He claims hersquos found a new calm. Also slang for lemonade.H is for Holyrood: Thatrsquos the ugly carbuncle which contains the parcel of rogues. The architect Enric Miralles had the good sense to peg it before the building was completed andbits keep dropping off it at the present rate therersquoll be a few MSPs joining him.I is for Indyref: Dunno where, dunno when, but wersquoll meet again. It will come.J is for Jakey: Itrsquos a derogatory term which has wider currency than just applying to an alcoholic or a homeless person, another of those Scottish slights, connoting some shambolic stumblebum you happen to despise. Itrsquos also for Jessie. As in Big, although thatrsquos probably been banned from the lexicon on correctness grounds.K is for Kelly, Lorraine, the love her or loathe her one from daytime telly and a slew of bad adverts.L is for Leonard: Not the clever one from the Big Bang Theory, the hapless one leading Scottish Labour down a black hole.M is for Minted: Someone with more disposable income than you. Itrsquos as much a term of envy as approval. M is also for Maroon. Itrsquos when you are in a bar and the minted one is reluctant to dig out his or her wedge and you say, ldquoWhatrsquos that colour Hearts play in again  and when they answer with the M word you respond, ldquoIrsquoll have a large whisky thanks.N is for Nippy. As in sweetie: It may well be a sexist term, because you donrsquot hear it being used about, say, a small and abrasive man, like Jimmy Krankie or Lenny again, but usually women.O is for Old Firm: Enough said.P is for Pure: Not, of course, the opposite of impure, but the adjective before brilliant. Or mental.Q is for Losers: We used to do it in an orderly way for buses and trains and at bars but now we just pile in with the elbows out. Also for Quaich, which is a shallow drinking bowl out of which whisky is lapped.R is for Rabbie. And Ruth: Theyrsquore not linked. Obviously. Onersquos a dead bard and some might say the otherrsquos dead bad for large swathes of Scotlandrsquos electorate. Ms Davidson has, fortunately for her, been on maternity leave while her national party combusts and the walking dead Prime Minister stumbles towards her end. Perfect timing for Ruth to emerge, smiling, and claim the Tory party mantle.S is for Stoater: An expression of approval of physical attributes, or someone, or something, bouncing off the walls. Stravaig. Or Steaminrsquo. Both of which often go together, an aimless inebriated walk, across heath, heather or the home doorstep. It used to be for Steamie too, but we donrsquot have these anymore.T is for Tacket: As in tackety boots, which had hobnails in the sole and gave off a trail of sparks when you slid, like a jet trail. Now we have to do with the likes of light-up trainers.U is for Uisge beatha: The stuff you put in the Quaich.V is for Vennel: The alley between houses, where many a wean was conceived,the close was too busy.W is for Wharsquos like us  That mantra of national insecurity dressed up as a cultural bond of superiority. Itrsquos also the first letter in the term of abuse related to a solo sexual practice and, together with a provocative hand sign, is pretty much applicable to anyone or anything disliked. Or it could be for Wallace, William, whose arms were so long his hands scraped the ground.X is for Xenophobe : Hating, quite often, the English, but any minority will do at a pinch. And Saltire, because it has a big cross , and thatrsquos also what you do on the ballot paper.Y is for Yesser or Yoon: Enough said.Z is for Zulu: Yes, we do have them, not the Rorkersquos Drt lot which saw off Michael Caine and company in the classic film, theyrsquore actually fishing boats that are used in the Moray Firth and further afield to catch herring. Although there canrsquot be many of them left, likewise the fish. And Zed, Sean Conneryrsquos character in the absolutely dreadful s sci-fi move Zardoz.

title: bbc-documentary-george-osborne-wanted-westminster-to-run-indyref
story: The controversial idea was considered, but rejected, after Liberal Democrat Ministers insisted the rules of the plebiscite should be set north of the border.The programme also revealed that former prime minister Gordon Brown wanted half of the money raised by the No side to go to Labourrsquos standalone campaign.The first episode of a three-part documentary - Yes No ndash Inside The Indyref - will look at the events which led to the announcement of the independence vote, the role of social media, and how the teams developed their strategies.It contains exclusive interviews with the key players during the referendum, and was made by Paul Mitchell, who was behind Inside Obamarsquos White House and The Death of Yugoslavia.The first episode includes the reaction amongst senior Westminster figures to the SNPrsquos landslide victory at the  Holyrood election, which paved the way for a referendum.However, in a  meeting of the ldquoquad - the key figures in the Tory LibDem coalition at Westminster - there was a discussion on London making the key decision.Nick Clegg, who at that point was the deputy prime minister, said: ldquoI remember at that meeting, George Osborne arrived late, and said half-seriously, half-jokingly, lsquocanrsquot we just run the referendum from London  Thatrsquos what they would do in Spainrsquo.Michael Moore, the then Scotland Secretary and Lib Dem MP, told the programme: ldquoHowever he meant it, it was considered. It took people like me and others to push back and say lsquowe will have to find a solution that is made in Scotland. If we try and do it from London, we will lose.Backing up Moorersquos account, Clegg said the Government had to ldquoavoid the trap of feeding the ldquogrievance narrative that the SNP liked to play.In another section, Osborne and Brown separately recalled a meeting that included former Prime Minister David Cameron on the campaign.Osborne said: ldquoGordonrsquos idea was that the Labour party should be put in charge of the campaign and the Tory party should fund it.Brown said: ldquoI said to them lsquolook, half the money should go to the Labour campaign. Labour should have a distinctive campaign.He added: ldquoLabour was best equipped to get this message across.Osborne responded: ldquoI donrsquot think that was a pretty sensible idea, frankly.Yes No ndash Inside The Indyref will be broadcast on Tuesday at pm

title: future-shock-we-scots-should-welcome-new-creationist-theme-park-where-humans-live-with-dinosaurs
story: One of these folk is the infamous Ken Ham, creationist founder of the ldquoArk Encounter theme park in Kentucky. Ham is currently hogging American headlines due to an ongoing dispute with atheist pressure group the Freedom From Religion Foundation ndash who believe Ham is a bit of a swine. The FFRF promotes the separation of church and government ndash a rather bold endeavour in a state where Governor Matt Bevin recently declared ldquoThe Year of the Bible. Perhaps, understandably, FFRF mostly carry out their protests by way of the internet ndash you canrsquot shoot the head off an online petition, after all.The group is furious that pound million in state tax incentives have helped fund Hamrsquos creationist theme park, yet ndash to be fair ndash some state officials did try to stop these generous tax breaks after learning the hardcore creationist entrepreneur would only hire Christians. Fuelled by the stimulant of self-righteous indignation, however, Ham decided to sue the state in federal court ndash and brought home the bacon by winning his case. Impressed Kentucky politicians then saw fit to reward his indefatigable faith with another wee rebate check for . million. Praise the Lord, indeed.With the penny finally dropping that there may perhaps be some sympathetic fundamentalist mindsets on governmental boards, FFRF has now recalibrated its aim and taken direct action ndash sending letters to more than , public schools around Kentucky to highlight the mind-warping dangers of taking advantage of Hamrsquos offer of free class field trips to Ark Encounter.Certainly, the statue of a smiling diplodocus at the entrance is indicative of a wilfully ignorant and wildly subjective interpretation of the Earthrsquos four-and-a-half billion year history. Yet, where traditional theme parks such as Blackpool Pleasure Beach ultimately confirm there is no God, Ark Encounter solely exists to solidy belief in a ine creator and His miraculous six-day endeavour.A gay old timeARK Encounterrsquos piegravece de reacutesistance is, like it says on the tin, an ldquoaccurate -feet-long recreation of Noahrsquos Ark ndash complete with animatronic models of dinosaurs and humans living together in harmony, just like in The Flintstones. And Job :ndash,creationist Biblical interpretations of the word ldquobehemoth are to be believed.Yet, in a move not quite in the spirit of Christrsquos New Testament message of acceptance and love, all employees at the park are required to sign a ldquostatement of faith which explicitly prohibits them from employmenttheyrsquore ldquogay, bi, or a person who has attempted to alter gender by surgery or appearance.Itrsquos perhaps then no surprise that Ham also has a concurrent campaign to, ahem, ldquotake back the rainbow. Which was,we recall Sunday School storytime, first gted to the Earth by temperamental Old Testament tyrant Yahweh himself ndash in a plea for forgiveness after killing everyone in a pique of petulant fury at our so-called ldquosins, such as homosexuality and the like. Itrsquos certainly ironic that despite being heavily influenced by The Flintstones, Ham certainly wonrsquot ever tolerate a ldquogay old time.Jockrsquos on usSCOTS are, of course, children of the Enlightenment, sensibly secular of mind and progressively liberal enough to have earned a wee condescending chuckle at the backward beliefs of some of our American cousins.Despite all evidence to the contrary, however, many of us remain within the confines of this self-gratying bubble of ldquowharsquos like us  nonsense. The truth is, wersquore perhaps even more societally regressive than any dusty, confederate backwater in the American heartlands.In , MSP Alasdair Allan ndash who was the Minister for Learning, Science and Scotlandrsquos Languages ndash saw fit to officially respond to pressure from the militantly atheist Scottish Secular Society , boldly stating the obvious to his peers in Holyrood: ldquoGuidance provided by Education Scotland does not identy Creationism as a scientic principle. It should therefore not be taught as part of science lessons.And neither should enriching uranium yet no-onersquos banned that yet. So, perhaps with that in mind, Allan fell short of outlawing the teaching of a six-day creation period by a prankster transdimensional magician ndash adding a rather timorous postscript that any precedents of governmental intolerance would inevitably lead to ldquocalls for bans on other issues and the curriculum would risk becoming mired in legal arrangements.One wonders whether Allanrsquos a**e is still numb from such an awkward perch on the fence. His non-committal stance does, however, echo successive Scottish and UK governmentsrsquo deeply ingrained reluctance to condemn, or even recognise, the bleeding chasm of ision for which religious dogma is almost entirely responsible. Most folk free from the micro-management of thought caused by this ancient virus can clearly see its butterfly effect of societal paralysis, and on a micro scale, calcying the neurones of its host to protect itself against rival contagions ndash or any wildly idealistic notions of utopic unity and global harmony.That the sediment of fear and superstition remains the fundamental layer we build our communities and education system upon in  is bad enough, but the fact religionrsquos stagnated stench still clogs the corridors of power is surely the ultimate absurdity ndash with Scottish local authorities still being legally obliged to cower under the overriding authority of Tha Lawd on council education boards.Return of the JediITrsquoS a law that surely proves wersquore all either numbed within a collective hypnotic state or that reality truly is a simulation run by malevolent aliens ndash the absurd ruling that Scottish councils are still legally required to appoint three education committee members to represent a transdimensional creator skyspirit. Legally, all require one Catholic representative, one Church of Scotland and one ldquoother. Perhaps a Jedi would be appropriate ndash as therersquos more chance of a Darth Vader figure existing in an infinite universe than a temperamental creator with suspiciously human traits such as jealousy, fury and regret.Yet, despite the comedic costumes being a dead giveaway to their shoogly grasp on reality, the pious are somehow bestowed with entirely unearned respect and privilege in our society, particularly within the corridors of power ndash despite their myopic belief systems infecting every warped thought and utterance.Itrsquos surely right that we question why unelected purveyors of fancul fiction can operate freely from voter accountably and bear influence on how our children are educated. South Lanarkshire Councilrsquos Dr Nagy Iskander is one such presence ndash a creationist who has said that evolution is ldquoreally illogical.Incidentally, Iskander counts Ark Encounterrsquos Ken Ham as a personal friend ndash perhaps admiring how he has earned a very comfortable living by convincing the naive and desperate that his self-serving porkies are the gospel truth.And finally ...PERHAPS there really is no need to rush any official ban on teaching creationism in Scottish classrooms.It could be argued itrsquos putting the cart before the horse in a country where we still appoint believers in ancient Abrahamic superstitions to education boards ndash and continue to segregate children in accordance to parental allegiances to a supernatural entity who only ever existed in our speciesrsquo minds.At least our Kentuckian cousins donrsquot believe their omnipotent comfort blanket has any allegiance to a particular sports team. Just last week, ldquoProtestant ldquoCatholic and ldquowest of Scotland were among the highest trending terms on UK twitter.Perhaps The Flintstones has simply evolved into a social media reality show, starring yabba dabba you and me. Therersquos certainly no need to build an Ark Encounter theme park in a country populated and led by dinosaurs, already fully submerged and drowning in destructive delusions.

title: advice for supporters ahead of scottish cup game at pittodrie
story: Police Scotland officers along with partners are preparing to welcome thousands of football fans to Aberdeen for the Scottish Cup Quarter Final this Sunday.Kick off for the Aberdeen and Rangers game is at .pm and so the City Centre, Pittodrie, Aberdeen Beach and Seaton areas will be busier than usual.Police ask that fans heading to the stadium plan their journeys in advance and allow themselves plenty of extra time to get to the stadium. Match Commander Superintendent Richard Craig is encouraging everyone planning to watch the game either at Pittodrie stadium, a licensed premises or in their home to enjoy the match but to behave responsibly. He said: “It is well-documented that drinking too much alcohol can lead you to become more vulnerable to becoming involved in crime either as a victim or perpetrator. I am urging supporters to behave responsibly and be aware thatyou’re drunk you won’t be allowed entry to the stadium and you’ll miss the match. “Anyone who does become involved in disorder or any act of violence will be dealt with robustly. “Additional officers will be on duty across the North East and within the stadium on Sunday and they will be supported by specialist resources. Our officers are extremely experienced in policing football matches and will be able to offer assistance should anyone need it.“Although the new AWPRis an option for travel we would still advise all football traffic coming from South of Aberdeen to use the traditional supporters’ route into the city .“We are here to ensure the safety and security of all supporters attending the game and minimise disruption to the local community. "I would remind supporters that those entering Pittodrie will be closely monitored for possession of alcohol or pyrotechnics of any kind. It is a condition of entry to the ground that fans allow themselves to be searched and those who refuse will be turned away by the club. “We will be implementing policing operations throughout the day, including spot checks on buses and coaches travelling to the game."Superintendent Craig added: “Pyrotechnics are extremely dangerous and endanger the safety of those around you as well as your own safety. We will take action, you will be arrested.“The match is undoubtedly a big event and we are looking forward to it. title: charities hold last entries to run garioch
story: The last few remaining places for Run Garioch are held by six local charities.This year’s Run Garioch charity partners are CLAN, Chest, Heart  Stroke Scotland, The Gathimba Edwards Foundation, Friends of the Neonatal Unit, Charlie House and Inspire PTL.
